description:
Looking further into the outer Sunset for sleeper Asian restaurants, I came up with this one for lunch.  Knowing as you may by now, my reviews always, or maybe just sometimes, come with self-admitted disclosures.  I'm a big fan of Asian restaurants in general and value being the only Anglo in the place.  Great if the waiter doesn't speak English.  And a big plus for a menu that would seem weird on the other side of town.  In other words, a Chinese dive that somehow makes me feel faraway is a great beginning, with incredible items made from what might in other cultures become petfood.  That's a 5star beginning for me. 

OK so Yan Yan is in a small commercial area in an otherwise solid residential neighborhood that goes on for quite a few blocks before ending at the beach.  Maybe it's the trolley line along Judah so the street is a bit less auto-friendly, but anyway not much commercial activity nearby.  From the outside Yan Yan says right off this is a dive mostly patronized by Asians.  Then you enter the place, and find yourself in the kitchen.  Don't let this put you off, keep going, turn right.  

Finally inside the tables are in a room totally lacking in decor except for a tv and one of those buddha shrines, both mounted high on the wall.  Formica tables and a few other basics are what you get to look at.  Maybe this is so you'll pay more attention to the food?  Whatever, this in my book is 5star, as I'm here to eat.  So, what for the food.  The menu is not the largest selection in town, but it's very expansive.  Items like chicken feet and pork belly are quite good for appetizers, but not always seen are pork intestines in several forms.  The servings are extremely generous, one table nearby with a large group was served a large mound of pork chops and an equally large portion of a chicken dish.  Our own mustard green with garlic was enough for four and then some.    

I'll have to go back as there are a lot of clay pot items and a great many seafood specialties to try.  But on a first outing, I am really encouraged.
author: Bob S.

description:
Solid Canto restaurant (verified by my Canto friends). Came here last night and there was no line. This is your typical Asian restaurant that you'd find in the SGV - not much decor, giant round tables, waitresses that only speak Canto, etc.

Food was solid! Chicken feet were complimentary appetizers. We ordered some sort of vegetable dish, spare rib, walnut shrimp, and the bird's nest noodles. All were good, but nothing spectacular. 

They added a 15% off tip automatically. Kinda weird, but at least they gave us two servings of dessert each. Probably cause my friends speak Canto!
author: Michael N.

description:
I've never stepped foot into this restaurant, but my classmate purchased a tray of salt and pepper chicken wings for our class potluck. They were A-MA-ZING! Everyone grabbed at least 4 wings and everyone asked where he got it from. 

The pictures of the food on Yelp look delicious as well and I will definitely make my way over there soon. My mouth is watering just thinking about it!
author: V M.

description: Food was not amazing ... service was mediocre as most host only spoke Chinese only it was hard to understand and get help as needed .
author: Dora V.

description:
Some of my favorites:
Beef short ribs with garlic 
Stir fried pea vines with garlic
Beef and tofu medallions

Not a fan of the salt and pepper spare ribs here, too much coating not enough flavor.

Manager is very outgoing and sweet. Will lead the happy birthday song.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
The best sweet & sour and salt & pepper pork chops in sunset district!  I know it's a super american and white dish to order but trust me, they're amazing here.  I'm crazy addicted to them.  The portions are huge and one order comes with at least 15-20 pieces... The same goes with all the other dishes.

Don't be alarmed if you hear a loud asian lady yelling from across the room.  That's just the boss lady here who is super friendly and welcoming.  During lunch there'll be waves of construction workers.  That's how you know a restaurant is inexpensive but delicious heh. 

Chicken feet is complimentary on the house if that's your kin as well ;)
author: Derek L.

description:
This is your typical Chinese restaurant. It's super packed and crowded, service is meh, cleanliness is questionable, and good food.

We had a large group on a Saturday night, we were stuffed in the corner area of the restaurant with very little wiggle room. Food came out fairly quick, no corkage fee for bringing our own wine bottles. 

12 dishes ordered, all was good, but nothing stood out as amazing. If I lived close, I would definitely stop by once in a while whenever my Chinese food cravings hit (for takeout), but I wouldn't drive out of my way from the East Bay.
author: Erica C.

description:
Good food! Good place to go when you don't feel like cooking. Not much of service but the owner is friendly and always make you feel like home. They have a large varieties to choose from the menu. The seafood is fresh and very tasty but quite a bit of oil on some dishes. Can't complain for the price and such a big plate. This restaurant has been around for many years. 
Definitely will be back again for a simple family dinner or order take out to bring home when my kitchen is closed and craving for Chinese food. Not a bad place to go for food!
author: Annie K.

description: The best Chinese restuarant in San Francisco. Food was delicious and good portion!! Great service! A must visit spot!!
author: Po C.

description:
I have a love-hate relationship with this place. I've been here many times over many years, where it has changed ownership and all that, and it seems to be worsening or something as time passes. Something happens when it gets crowded, they really do not know how to handle everything or more than one order at a time.

There is truth to the other reviews, the food is really good, but the service is TERRIBLE. This past time, we sat down, but no one took the order, so we had to go the front and basically place our order. But in a new twist for a restaurant, we had to write down our order, YES WRITE, and return it to the front woman (yes she's the only one who takes orders).

We got our first dish an hour after we sat down. I think other tables that sat after us got banquet dinners so their food came out quicker somehow, as if deviating from a set menu must confuse the kitchen. Dishes came out in no particular order and in no timely fashion.

What should be an hour activity turned into almost a 2.5 hour excursion into what should be the depths of a Restaurant Impossible episode.
author: Spencer H.

description:
Super delicious & flavorful entrees for reasonable
price points. We tried the:

* 1/2 peking spareribs and 1/2 salt & pepper spareribs 
* salty shredded chicken with cilantro 
* eggplant & minced pork with spicy szechuan sauce (not that spicy) 

All three dishes were packed with their own unique flavors reminiscent of ones I look for in chinese entrees when eating out. 

*Also comes with complimentary desserts @ the end. I recommend the mango pudding.
author: Ying Ci H.

description: Where to begin? They will over charge you any chance they get, service is terrible, manager will ignore you. I ordered take out and was charged $35 for an $11.99 and a 12.99 dish. I asked for an explanation and was ignored by the boss lady at the register because she said she was busy on the phone. After standing right in front of her for about 5 minutes, I called the restaurant and when she picked up MY call. I told her to look at me and explain my bill. After dancing around the fact that she over charged me on purpose, she settled on the excuse that she charged me $5 for the take out boxes and "added a tip" by mistake. I told her to take her food back and give me a refund and she pretty much threw $10 in my bag and told me to leave and not come back. Please do not come to this place!!!!
author: Tommy C.

description: As with most canto restaurants you don't go for the service, you go for the food. Yan Yan is no exception. The quality of the food is good, I would recommend the beef chow fun, the Hong Kong style fried Noodles, and the Yin Yang ribs. Portion size will surprise you, you really get more bang for your buck here! Will definitely return!
author: Melody F.

description: Interesting place.  Nothing special when it comes to decor, because there is no decor.  Service was good, but I've had better dishwater than their complimentary soup.  We accidentally order two fried dishes but both the salt & pepper prawns and salt & pepper chicken wings we're the bomb.  We also ordered the chicken fried rice and it was almost tasteless.  Needed salt or something.  Was an experience but we probably won't be back, well maybe for the salt and pepper dishes.
author: Scott S.

description:
Consistently high quality Chinese food! Truly one of the hidden gems of San Francisco! My favorite item here is their steamed surf clam, although I don't think I've ever had anything bad from here. This place is the Tim Duncan of authentic Cantonese food; the high quality output is so consistent every time, diners start taking it for granted and it gets boring. 

Other notable items here: tofu and seafood clay pot, yin yang pork chops, dried scallops & egg whites fried rice, and garlic fried chicken. Delightful!

As a bonus, they offer a dessert item! :P
author: Willk W.

description:
1. No one even give you glance even the waiter walk  around pass you by times. The cashier (the owner?) just stand behind the counter in front of you. Don't even bother to say a damn word while I waiting for serve 
2. Ppl came after us waiting long enough then ask how long will it be while there is a table vacant, the frozen face cashier just squeezed words out of her mouth' no table before you order'. And not move her eyes away from the cash machine while saying. I go like wtf am I in a ghost house. I run out of there at once. Don't give a shit how other review say the food is good
author: Mike S.

description:
THE WORST SERVICE of ANY restaurant I've ever been to!!! They really don't try or give any f*cks. The two ladies that walk around are consistently giving nothing but negative vibes. If you want attitude that's what you will be served here fast and plenty. These are people who have enough money to afford to open a restaurant but have no experience in "front of the house service." They're probably all relatives who have always wanted to open a restaurant, but never did research on how to operate one. They act as if your bugging them for drink orders or something they are missing like a serving spoon.

This is unfortunate because when the food finally makes it to your table it is good. Not outstanding, but good. They don't reinvent the wheel or have a signature dish. This place is always pretty crowded too. When you see 3/4 of the tables occupied be aware it will be a 2 hour experience. 

I can't go on anymore but reading the other reviews and realize the pattern here: Service sucks, food is decent whenever they decide to bring it out, desserts are good, AND LASTLY double check your bill to make sure you're not overcharged. This has happened two times after another patron advised us to do so.
author: Rob M.

description:
I love this place! The food is SO DAMN GOOD.

Be prepared to wait. They serve one table at a time. So a table of 14 will order like 10 dishes and they'll get all of there's, then the next table and so on. 

Service was just okay when we went here for dinner on a Saturday night with a table of about 8 ppl. Don't expect good service here. I had to grab sauce from an empty table because they were not so attentive. 

They give out free cold chicken feet appetizer that are just okay 2/5. I ate 1/2 of one only cuz I was starvinggg.

My top three dishes were 1/2 sweet sour/salt pepper ribs, cod fish with greens and whole flounder. 

I LOVE THE RED BEAN DESSERT 5/5.. I'm craving it right now. It's warm and soupy and not too sweet and oh so delicious. 

Come here for the food if you have a lot of time to wait for it and don't mind dealing with below average service! The food is so worth it, I'd put up with the service lol.
author: Leah A.

description: What a neighborhood gem in Sunset area. Must order the Hakka style pork belly with mustard green. So difficult to find this dish that is done right, not greasy nor salty. The pumpkin salty egg crab is a bomb. We ordered the quail which is their signature dish. It does not disappoint us. Portion is big and price is reasonable. Will definitely come back.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Get ready for some yummy grubby Cantonese food! 

I love their steamed black bean, soy sauce oysters and have been craving for it ever since.  It has hit that spot.  Their stir-fried, black bean clams were fresh and there were no crunchy sands in it.  I was awaiting for it and that shows that their clams are treated well.

Their pea sprouts in garlic, was good for a veggie dish. Their Mongolian beef, lacked a load of beef.  There were more slices of onions and green onions than the meat.  Tofu with mushrooms was aye okay as well as their fish cod with tender greens.  Their Westlake beef soup, was pretty bland.  I needed to sprinkle some white pepper to appease the palate.  

Service was not so good.  Didn't dine in, but my family ordered to go and the waitress who picked up, was giving attitude and impatiently asked for the orders. She didn't even repeat the dishes we ordered to confirm that it was right.  Maybe a bad day, but doesn't mean you take it out on customers.  

Good Canton food, but service and probably décor needs to be revamped to make it a customer-friendly environment. Otherwise, this place will not have customers (such as myself) returning on a consistent basis.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Everyone who works here is always so kind and hard working. You see the same familiar faces working all the time. Family style Chinese food, pretty standard. We come for family dinners often. Good hot food can't complain. Also love the desserts at the end of the meal!
author: Katrina L.

description:
Service was terrible.
Made a reservation for 6pm, arrived and took our order in about 15min. At that time, there were still quite a lot of empty tables. 30min after our order was placed, the restaurant was packed with people. 
Our first dish came after 7pm, we literally waited almost AN HOUR to eat. We ordered 6 dishes, the last dish arrived at 8pm. They bring out one dish almost every 15-20min. It was VERY unsatisfying to eat when only one plate of dish comes out AFTER you have finish your first dish. Since it was almost 8pm and our last hasn't arrived so I asked if it's coming soon, if not then we can cancel the order, pay and leave (don't wanna be wasting my time). The waitress literally said "oh it's going to take a while for it to come out" I was feeling annoyed already since it has been almost 2 hours and the last dish which was a veggie dish, hasn't even arrived. 
Food was pretty decent. 
They were pretty good, would come back for the food but definitely NOT worth waiting 2 hours just to wait for the dishes to come one by one. 

To-go might have been a better option.
author: Ching C.

description: We were given two teapots on the table. One with tea bags and one without. Our understanding is that when the one with tea bags runs out of water, we pour the one in the other teapot to the now empty one.  That's exactly what we did and the server came over and demonstrated what we should be doing when we run out of water: open the lid and let it sit on the table. The point is we didn't completely run out of water, we had it on the other pot!  And we didn't call her over!!  When we told her we were just getting water from the other teapot, she asked why we are wasting each other's time?!  Excuse me?! It's totally uncalled for!
author: Justine L.

description: I didn't like this place the first time I came...it took us 30-40 minutes to order because there's only one person (the owner) that takes your order. After coming the second and third time, this place kind of grows on you. You have to be VERY ASSERTIVE to order food. You get sooooooo much for what you pay for, portions are HUGE, unlimited chicken feet (appetizer) and unlimited dessert. I saw 2 people eating close by, they had finished eating and while they were packing up, there was sooooo much food that it didn't even fit into the box, that's how much food they give you. At other places if you ordered takeout, the lid would have at least closed. I've also tried all the desserts. I personally only like the mango pudding and black sesame soup (a little too much tapioca starch though), the rest of the desserts I'll pass.
author: Kylie L.

description:
I haven't been here in years!  Not since the original owners were in charge.  We came here for a family dinner.  We ordered one of the big banquet dinners.  I didn't like the peking ribs.  I found that there was too much breading on the ribs but boy did they give you a lot.  It's like a mound of meat!  The other dishes were ok.  THe fish did not have a lot of meat.  They fried the flounder head and bones and threw veggies and the fish meat on top.  Come on there has got to be more meat than that!

Food wasn't salty it was ok.  Kudos for your choice of free dessert.  Service was friendly but slow.  It was a two hour dinner and usually we're done by an hour!

Parking around here is a bitch!
author: Wendy H.

description: Just got back from a horrible experience. For starters, there was no one to take your order. After sitting there for 10 minutes, another table saw our frustration and said that they too had the same problem. Eventually, some person came by and dropped off a pen and paper and told us to write down what we wanted! Though we had questions about the menu, they basically blew us off and told us to write it down. Now my folks are 92 and 88 years old, so getting up and leaving for another restaurant was not an option. So if you're ok with bad service, then you might be okay with the food. They are slick though because they add the tip to the bill, so you are stuck with the bad service with no recourse. I looked around and other tables seemed happy with the food (large portions), but I will not be back. They are way too many places to spend your dining dollars, rather than waste it at a place with the worst service imaginable (and I've been to lots of places with spotty service). 4 dishes, total bill with forced tip...86 bucks. Fool me once...
author: Harlan W.

description:
Customer service is non existent at this place. I called to place a delivery and the person on the phone said they don't offer delivery, and said, "bye, bye", and hung up without even giving me an option to respond. When I called back I said i wanted to place an order for pick up. The same person picked up the phone and had zero phone manners. I was constantly  interrupted and put on hold while placing my order without even being asked to hold on or having the other person excuse themselves. I had to repeatedly ask the person on the other end if they were still there or if they heard what I said because they were talking to some customers inside the restaurant while I was placing my order.  When I was done ordering I asked in how long I should pick up the order, and they said they will call me back. They couldn't even give me a rough estimate. I have never heard anything so outrageous before. Every place that I have ordered food from gives some estimate, rather than saying they will call back. That is just weird! Also, the total wasn't given to me. 

The restaurant didn't give us what we ordered, yet charged us for it, and when we we called to tell them they didn't include all our items they argued with us and accused us of lying. After I had placed my order over the phone, I had asked the person to repeat my order and they repeated all the items I ordered, meaning they just failed to includel my items. What a bunch of deceitful thieves!!! Food is disgusting. Stay away from this place.
author: Emily G.

description:
The major drawback to this restaurant is that the service is SLOW. It seems that only the boss lady can take orders and all the other waiters serve food. It's a bit mind boggling that with a fairly big restaurant serving about 10+ tables that you can only get service from one person. We definitely practiced patience as we waited about 10 minutes just to order. However, I was pleased to see the food arrive pretty quickly. 

Overall, come to Yan Yan for decent food, decent prices, and decent portions.
author: Briana H.

description: Lots of food at reasonable prices. Each dish is a very large portion, so it's best to come with a group of people. They have lots of old time Chinese comfort food...braised pork belly, steamed eggs, clay pot specialties, etc. Everything is very tasty and satisfies my home cooking cravings!
author: Annie W.

description:
This restaurant is a pretty good Cantonese restaurant if you're looking for a relaxed conversational meal. When you first walk in you'll see some tanks with crustaceans, which makes sense since it's a seafood restaurant. The atmosphere is very casual and truthfully a bit loud, but I guess it gives it a relaxed mood. 

The food is overall satisfying, as there are ups and downs for the food and service. The food is pretty good, however some dishes like the fried ribs (pai ku/拍酷) are a bit too salty. The vegetable dishes in a way balance out the heaviness of ribs and meats in sauces. On the other hand, the staff is friendly enough, but it may be a bit hard getting their attention unless they're patrolling, in which you can kind of flag them down. The food here may not be the best, but hey it's still pretty good.

A couple dishes I would suggest are the seafood soup, sweet and sour ribs, beef fried rice noodle, and fried bean leaf (or something like that). You should try this restaurant if you want some good Chinese food while you talk to family and friends.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
My family made reservations for NYE and we were seated in a private room past the bathrooms. After placing our orders we were forewarned that food was going to take a while to come out because they were really busy. 

F O U R T Y - F I V E M I N U T E S later...
The "kids" table got their first dish. 15mins later, the "kids" table started getting all their dishes. The adults started to take from our table. They didn't get their food until about 30mins after us. 

When we left, i didn't realize we were there for almost 2.5hrs, all of which consisted of waiting. It was ridiculous! I understand that you're busy but waiting over an hour for food is unacceptable.
author: Serena F.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night (reservation made in the afternoon same day) with a group of eight. It was 7:30pm and the restaurant was fully packed. Not much decorations, but it indeed looks very much like an authentic Chinese restaurant.

The dishes on menu are pretty standard. Asked the waitress to take order but every one was telling us to wait until the lady boss's free and she will take the order for us. We literally waited for 10 minutes until the lady boss came to our table - was a bit frustrated about that. But once she started taking our order, I totally understand why we had to wait for her - the lady boss is hilarious, the way she speaks and her body language is very interesting; and she has the complete menu memorized and offered good suggestions on what we should get. It was quite an entertaining "show".

Chicken Feet 鹵水白雲鳳爪 (appetizer): A-.
The best part of it was free of charge - they literally gave us two big plates of chicken feet. For chicken feet, usually there are only either black bean taste (where you find from dim sum) or those cold, boiled+vinegar style (white in color). It was probably the first time I tried this particular 鹵水白雲 type and it was pretty amazingly good.

Crab + Fish Stomach Soup 蟹肉魚肚羹: B+.
It was alright. Pretty standard.

Jelly Fish Smoked Meat 海哲薰蹄: B+.
It was alright. No surprise there.

Salted Fish Tofu Chicken Pot 鹹魚雞粒豆腐煲: B+.
Nothing special. Would appreciate more if the salted fish smell could come out more from the pot.

Tofu Pea Sprouts 玉子豆腐大豆苗: A-.
The stir fry time was controlled really well - the pea sprouts was perfectly cooked and the vege quality itself was very good. 

Kyoto Prime Ribs + Salt and Pepper Fried Ribs 京都＋椒鹽排骨: B.
We couldn't decide which flavor to get, and so the lady boss said we can just order half an order from each flavor. It wasn't the best thing to do actually, because by doing that the Kyoto flavor did not get much sauce to it, while the salt and pepper flavor did not taste deep fried enough. I suggest to go with either flavor instead of both.

Stir-fry Bean 炒四季豆: A-.
I think they used 馬拉盞 as the sauce and it indeed smelled and tasted very nice. Not too much oil was used so didnt get stuffed afterwards.

Hand-sheared Salty Chicken 手撕鹽焗雞: A-.
Surprisingly good. It was sheared into small pieces which made it very easy to eat. Taste was very flavorful - definitely on the salty side, but I mean it is 鹽焗 so it is completely normal. The addition of green onion further enhance the smell and taste to the dish. We ordered one whole chicken, and it seems to be just about the right amount for eight people.

Stir-fried Clam 避風塘炒蜆: A-.
I have not tried this type of clam-cooking method before - it was first deep fried and then stir-fried with pepper and hot chili sauce - and it wasn't too spicy. Clam was pretty fresh. Would recommend to finish this dish at the earliest since it tasted much better when the dish was still hot.

Steamed Fish 清蒸石斑: A.
The fish itself was very fresh. Cooking time was perfect. Couldn't really criticize this dish.

After dinner, it's free dessert time! So there were choices of 龜零膏/芝麻糊/芒果布丁/紅豆沙. I tried the mango pudding and it was alright - definitely not made with fresh mango but it did not taste bad. My friends who got the 龜零膏 said it was really good, and 芝麻糊 had some strange texture to it.

When we left the restaurant, the lady boss came out and said bye to us. All of a sudden she started singing some old Chinese songs so loud that the whole street could listen. Haha it was pretty hilarious.

Overall, a pretty decent Chinese little restaurant, with lots of above standard dish choices and entertaining boss. I totally wouldn't mind coming back to Yan Yan again.
author: Simon C.

description: Ordered takeout from here for dinner. The proportions and prices are great here, I would definitely recommend ordering the salt & pepper ribs. It can be a hit or miss because the previous time I ordered it, it got overfried. They give generous portions of egg for the fried rice.
author: Erica K.

description:
Went on a Sunday night. The place was packed and almost always is, especially for dinner. We got the fried flounder, mustard greens with mushroom, and half half pork chops (half sweet and sour, half salt and pepper). I must say, all three dishes were delicious. I highly recommend the half half pork chops because they were really on par. The flounder, I would rather have steamed but if you like a food crunch to your fish, then get the fried flounder.

You also get a free plate of chicken feet. The owner/manager is super friendly (can't say the same about the rest of the staff but I didn't have that much of an interaction with them). At the end of the meal, each diner gets to choose from a list of desserts too (red bean soup, green bean soup, herbal jelly, mango pudding, black sesame soup). The red bean soup was good and standard. The herbal jelly was ok but I'm biased because I don't like it anywhere.

All in all, I'd come again to see what else is good or just for those pork chops again!
author: Christine L.

description:
No doubt a 100% legit Cantonese style restaurant.  Prices are extremely reasonable, menu is extensive, food is tasty (look at the pics, says more than a thousand words).  This is not Panda Express or PF Chang's for sure.  Some must orders:

If you are adventurous, the squab (fancy name for pidgeon) is very tender and flavorful.  In a blind taste test, you could be fooled in thinking it's duck.  Avoid looking at the heads, which by the way could be eaten.

When in season, the pea shoots are fantastic.  It has the right blend of garlic and cooked perfectly.

BTW, the hostess (I think is the owner) is extremely eccentric in a good way and engaging.  You may get a few laughs in chatting with her.

For everything that is great about the restaurant, few minor downsides.  Parking is limited to the neighborhoods, best shot is really on Judah St.  It's very cramped and don't mind that people may bump into you.  Also, you could be intimidated with the all Chinese vibe (tip: make a Chinese friend to take you here).

Highly recommended!
author: Addie L.

description: Customer service is horrible .  Try to go there for lunch with a co-worker . Restaurant just open for lunch . Owner -PMS dragon lady. Waited for 15mins. Restaurant is empty.  Dragon lady told me . No table for two people during lunch time wtf . We will have to wait and share a table.  B.S..we left .
author: Joseph L.

description:
...like I mentioned before in most of my reviews in Chinese restaurants.. The only time you'll find me in a Chinese restaurant is when I'm having dinner with family. So of course that's what happened on this past Tuesday night. 

My parents mentioned before about a particular restaurant that they like cause the food is really good portion and a bang for your buck. I didn't know they were talking about Yan Yan though. So long long time ago, my grandparents along with my parents and other relatives used to run this place before they split off to open their own individual restaurants. I honestly don't remember those days since I was a wee little baby. Haha

The food is definitely tasty & big portioned. They also give you complimentary mini desserts that you can choose such as mango pudding, red bean soupie, black sesame soupie, & etc. 

Parking shouldn't too difficult since the place is located in a residential area.
author: Amy C.

description: One of my favorite chinese restaurant. They give out free chicken feet and desert. I love the fish cod,tofu clay pot. And their honey glazed short ribs.
author: Bonnie C.

description:
We hadn't been back here for dinner in years but a group of 10 friends got together and ordered a table of food that could've easily fed 12-14.  Portions are generous. There was alot of leftovers to take home.  The tab was over $300 which came to $30 per person and included the auto 15% tip.  I was told the owners changed again. The dining room is larger and brighter now. 

We started off with a platter of sliced beef, pork and jellyfish which was tender compared to Chewy strands at other places.  We also had complimentary cold but seasoned soy chicken feet.  Other dishes included sautéed squid with Vegts., salted chicken, the walnut shrimp was great, my favorite was the mixed salt pepper beef and Peking beef, the catfish in black bean sauce was tender, 2 fried crabs were tender as well.  I don't particularly like mustard greens with mushrooms but the Vegt was cooked just right.  

At the end of the meal you select red or green  bean soups which were good, sesame soup was sweet but too thick, mango pudding was too stiff and not so great. The herbal turtle shell jello was nasty as it had a bitter taste and you have to eat it with the sweet syrup. It was a good Chinese multi-course meal.
author: Ry T.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants because of good food quality with reasonable prices.  The owner is very friendly and easy to deal with.  When it is a full house, there isn't enough space for people to walk through.
author: Patrick L.

description: Delicious and cheap, they give me red bean congee for free! I like the dessert they serve after meal. But their female waitresses are not nice, not willing to give me the togo boxes.
author: Eva Z.

description:
I've been going to this restaurant since I was a little kid. Though the owners have changed, the food tastes just as great! The owner has excellent customer service. I went on a saturday night with my family and luckily there were tables available at 7:30 PM. We sat down, and an appetizer of chicken feet was given as a complementary side. I always crave their chicken feet. My brother, who rarely eats chicken feet dug in graciously. He said these were the only chicken feet he would eat since. I was amazed at what I saw. 

My family of 4 decided to order a pot of tofu with fried fish and mushrooms, honey walnut shrimp, a type  of bird (i dont know the name), egg whites fried rice, and a sweet and sour pork. After we ordered, it took the waiters about 20 minutes to bring out our first dish. It was a bit slow but there were many people to service so I understood. 

The food was amazing. After the first dish arrived, the other dishes soon followed. The egg whites fried rice is the best! Though I try to make it at home, the best ones are always made here. The sweet and sour pork is one of my favorites here. For such a big plate, it only costs around $9. That's SUPER cheap! Its one of the main reasons why I like eating here. Good price for a good meal. 

Though I havn't  been here in awhile, I did not know they still gave out free dessert of your choice. You could choose from red bean, green beans, mango pudding to black sessame dessert. I chose mango pudding because it's my favorite dessert at an asian restaurant. 

Overall, the food was great and the service was great. Though they are a bit slow on bringing out the dishes, I think the food compensated for that. Yan Yan, I will definitely be back!
author: Tiffany L.

description: Very good service and food!! Staff's are very friendly and the serve soup and free tasty appetizer at the beginning,  they also served dessert at the end. The food was awesome! I tasted the best sweet and sour pork in my life there! The portion of the food is big, I need to pack boxes home for dinner and lunch!
author: Yuet C.

description: Horrible service. Called for takeout, they told me I had to order it a day ahead. Second time I called for takeout, they told me to call back in a few hours . This place is a joke.
author: David S.

description: I'm sitting here now after 30 minutesof being ignored by waiters and the hostess. We flagged down two of them and they acknowledged and then waved us off. Food is usually good and they have large portions but the service is absolute shit. They only have one person taking orders.
author: Melissa L.

description:
Great food, haven't had a chance to eat Chinese for a couple of months and this was delicious. The sweet and sour pork chops was delicious. I loved the soup and I thought it was great how they allowed everyone to offer their own dessert instead of bringing out a whole bowl. The mango pudding wasn't anything special, but the other desserts were all good. 

I left very full, happy, and satisfied. Heads up service isn't that great, but it's to be expected at an Asian restaurant.
author: Pryscilla T.

description: Went to this place for dinner last night with the family.  This was our first time at this establishment.  So far, thumbs up.  The food was very good, the portion are great.  The service might be slow but the food makes up for it.  The prices are reasonable.  The owner, she was very nice and friendly.  We will return for lunch and dinner soon.
author: Jan S.

description:
Come here with friends for lunch on Saturday at 11:15. We were the first ones there.

FOOD - 4.5 **** so yummy and big portions! They gave us cold chicken feet appetizers on the house. We ordered fish-tofu claypot. Very good. Shrimp-egg gravy chow fun. Delicious and big portion. Dried scallop and seafood soup was on the bland side. Pea shoots was a huge order but very good. Jellyfish and pork appetizer was tasty.

RESTAURANT - 3 *** There seemed to only be one waitress when we got there which was fine in the beginning but then more than half the restaurant was filled within 30 minutes and the service got slow. Later more wait staff seemed to show up, but still slow. Lots of big tables in the restaurant for groups. Also not a fan of incense smells while I eat...

PRICE- 4 **** For good quality Chinese food, definitely worth it!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Yan Yan Seafood Restaurant is a Chinese hole-in-the wall. It is built in the bottom floor of a house-looking building and residents live upstairs. This is my family's go-to place when all my extended members come together. We have been coming here for at least the last 3 years come here for my grandparent's birthdays or other occasions and I am never disappointed. They are open everyday except Tuesdays. The food is CHEAP, the portions are HUGE, and service is EXCELLENT. 

My most recent visit was last night. We got two orders of the set meal of $188 plus two additional dishes for 18 people. Every table gets a complimentary cold chicken feet dish as appetizers. Most kids of this generation might not eat it since it is more of a traditional dish, but I love it considering I'm not a picky eater and I love eating traditional Chinese food. The dishes are always really good. Their wok has a really good heat and makes everything super delicious. The Yin-Yang spareribs dish is my favorite. It is half sweet & sour spare ribs and half salt & pepper spare ribs. The walnut shrimp is always made perfectly. Nowadays, it is hard to find a place that makes perfect honey walnut shrimps. The complimentary dessert is another plus. Each person gets a choice of red bean soup, green bean soup, sesame dessert, mango pudding, or turtle shell jello. They are usually very lenient and if you want an extra dessert, they wouldn't mind giving you another one. 


The waiters and waitresses are pretty nice. They listen to all your commands and give you more than what you need. If you ask for one fork, they will give you three forks. If you ask for napkins, they will give you a huge stack.  

The boss lady is quite a character. If it is your birthday, she will sing with you at your table and will provide complimentary steamed buns. She has funny jokes (if you understand Cantonese). Also, if you are under 21, she will give you a jello treat. (Too sad I cant get them anymore).


One star off because the restaurant itself is kind of dirty and grimey.
author: Allie Y.

description:
Awesome Chinese food. Great portions and standard low prices but the quality definitely isn't diminished. Whenever I want to order for pick up I always choose yan yan (over all the other Chinese places on Irving).

Sometimes, if you're lucky enough, you'll see the owner who is a BO$$ lady. She is super friendly and is always flossed up with diamonds everywhere.
author: Dylan L.

description: Surprisingly good neighborhood eats. The portions are huge and the flavors are good. The veggie dishes double as 2. The staff is friendly and the prices are cheap.
author: Julie L.

description:
A small neighborhood restaurant, great food, good portions, great flavors. We had a family dinner for 6 with an upgrade from crab to the chef's special deep fried lobster dish. The owner graciously offered us the half and half pork dish mentioned by many reviewers. Sweet sticky, crunchy goodness. I was unsure about the whole fried fish but it was delicious and we ate almost all of the fish. 

It is cash only, they include the tip and if you should be inclined to tip more the staff will decline the extra. The owner is a very busy, gracious lady who took the time to make sure we enjoyed our dinner and invited us back in the future.

Definitely will be making this a regular stop when we're in the city.
author: Dave H.

description: Complimentary chicken feet for app & all you can eat dessert - choose from 5!  Tasty food and generous portion.  Get busy fast, need to make reservation.  Can get tight.
author: Gloria H.

description:
This is your typical Cantonese Chinese restaurant with good portions for a reasonable price, because of that this place does get busy and waits are expected.The reason for deducting two stars on the rating is due to the  restaurant being ran inefficiently and  them trying to squeeze as many people as people in a very tiny restaurant. 

When dining here be aware that it will take awhile to get your food ordered as the boss lady is the only person that is allowed to take food orders. The rest of the staff only serves and cleans the dishes, so when the restaurant is busy it will definitely take awhile to get your food down. Secondly, this restaurant is very cramped and you are literally sitting back to back with other patrons. 

One more note, this place does not do take-out orders when it's busy, seems like the chef can't handle too many orders. 

So if you're planning to dine here, I recommend you to make reservations!
author: Lucy C.

description:
Thank you Cat for great lunch and hospitality!

Sizzling seafood rise soup + sautéed seafood + dried sautéed string been + assorted vegetable rice noodle was great for three adults and one baby princess daughter. 

Will be back for some Mango pudding.
author: Slava C.

description: Located in the outer Sunset, the food is good with large portions.  The cons of this place is difficult to find parking, not super clean but this is standard for most hole in the wall Chinese restaurants.  The hostess who is also the owner can be moody so don't expect to be greeted with a smile.  Prices seem to be slightly higher than others but the large portions makes it worth the difference.  Whether you get take out or eat-in, you won't be disappointed with the amount of food they give you.  If you eat-in, they will give you complimentary chicken feet and desserts.  Definitely a place to re-visit.  Highly recommended.
author: Anna T.

description:
That was a lovely first experience! The head lady in charge was very sociable and likable. She will make a point to chat you up. We had an odd number of 5 people so it was a bit difficult to get a table since most tables were very large or a table for 4. We waited 1 hour but the average wait time was ~15 minutes. To apologize for the long wait, the head lady gave us half a plate of 鳯爪 on the house.

My favorite dishes from tonight included their signature lobster and 豆苗 with mushrooms and tofu. Yum yum!  Everything else was at the very least decent and the size for the price was of good value!

My favorite part was that they allowed you to pick your choice of dessert (for each member at the table too!) I hate being forced to eat overcooked sweet bean soup... I got the 龟苓膏 with sweetener and ginger instead. Mmm!
author: Jannet H.

description: BEWARE. This restaurant has the worst service I have ever experienced. Made reservation for Mother's Day three weeks in advance for 5 pm. Got there to the restaurant on time but the owner did not open the door until 5:20 pm while all these patrons were waiting outside. Finally got seated and  there was no wait staff to take our order. Tried many times to get the waitress's attention but she just bobbed and walked away.  Long story short, we didn't get our orders in until 40 mins later. We waited for an hour and 40 mins before my patience went out and walked out. I would have love to rate their food if we were ever served. What is the point of making reservation if the the table next to us came @ 6pm and were served first. This owner does not know how to run a business and certainly ruined Mother's Day for me.
author: Suzy Y.

description:
+ THE FOOD
Came here for a birthday dinner and was surprised by how big the portion sizes were. The food is piled high on the plates and it'll be a miracle if you can finish it all. I liked how they served marinated chicken feet as their free appetizer because it was unique and not typically seen in many restaurants. My favorite dishes were the tong choi, salt and pepper pork chops, honey walnut shrimp, and shredded salt-baked chicken. The desserts are great too because there's a huge variety (mango pudding, red bean dessert, chinese green mung bean dessert, sesame paste, gui ling gao) and all you need to do is tally off how many of each desserts you want, which means you can get more than 1 thing!!
author: Cindy C.

description: Waited for a hour of reservation not even the host came out, lagging and ignoring but serve the rest of the table.
author: Steven C.

description:
My family came here as a last minute decision on Xmas eve since my parent don't know that many places book up if you don't reserve them on a holiday evening! No worries, though, it got us to try this lil gem tucked away in the Sunset district away from other big restaurants. 

Despite that this place was a bit hidden away (it's clearly a local SF favorite though!), it was busy busy busy. They had all their large tables reserved, leaving just a handful of small table seating for parties 4 or smaller. We had a bit of a wait (30 min), but it wasn't horrible considering it was a holiday!

Prices are insanely cheap for the quantity of food here. And this is not a place where you have to choose quantity over quality either! We were very impressed with every dish that came out. We got a seafood egg drop soup, walnut shrimp (my brother loves this stuff...), chicken lettuce wraps, fried flounder, noodles, and an off menu order of greens/mushrooms/carrots. All was delicious and definitely served 4-6 people. We ended up ordering too much since the plates were huge, and had to take the majority of the noodles and greens home. Just means we get a delicious lunch of leftover the next day! With tax, this came out to ~$65 for 4 people!!

Extra pluses? Free chicken feet for the appetizer and free red/green bean soup, mango pudding, grass jelly, or sesame for dessert. Can't beat free food that also tastes good! 

While some of the staff were particularly sweet and attentive (we got a cute older lady who was great!), I docked a star for the wait time and for the fact that some of the staff really don't know some of the menu items well and literally shove you out of the way to serve tables. Granted, they're in a tight space at this restaurant, but some common courtesy to customers is always appreciated. 

If you haven't been to a more hole in the wall chinese restaurant, just keep in mind that wait times can be long, and that the focus is on the food, not necessarily the atmosphere or service. 

They take card here, but much more prefer (and urge you to..) cash. Overall, great place. We'll be back!
author: Teresa P.

description:
We got there around 11:30 a.m. on a Saturday.  Some of their tables were still available (Take an empty table).  All of their tables were taken around noon.  Their service can be slow due to that they served food for each tables at a time.  In another words, after they served all the dishes for one table, they would proceed to do same to the next table.  Chicken feet were served as complimentary.

We had the ying yang spareribs, lamb with leeks, seafood pan fried noodles and assorted mushrooms, tofu with pea sprouts.  The bigger portion of entrees matched the higher prices.  Their prices are reasonable.  We had mango puddings at the end of the meal.  I discovered a small piece of thread in it which I tossed out.  Overall the food tasted better than other Cantonese restaurants.  Expect longer service wait if you expect full service.  Faster service for placing order and checking out if you look for the female boss in the front near the entrance.  Appreciated for other yelpers' advice.
author: Steve T.

description:
It seems like every other month I am here for an extended family gathering.  And the truth is I love this place.  Sure, the service might be questionable and wait times vary, but it's our go-to spot and has become so familiar to us.  I wouldn't recommend going here unless you have a Cantonese speaking member in your party.  I'd also highly recommend making reservations and speaking in Cantonese when making the reservations.  This is a true legit Cantonese restaurant - be prepared for some Cantonese loudness and bluntness.  

Some good to know tips:
- We call this the "dessert place" because you can order as much dessert as you want.
- If you're celebrating a birthday, you can bring a cake and they will bring it out after you meal is done.  The boss lady will also come out and sing Happy Birthday in Cantonese and English.  It's quite a hoot.
- I believe there are certain days that their credit card machine doesn't work, so prepare to bring cash. 
- Try going with a big group and order one of the set menus
author: Olivia L.

description: This place is bomb.com don't expect great service though when you come here. Just come for the food. Also, this place usually packed with group. Be ready to wait or go somewhere else
author: Marcell R.

description:
We had delicious won ton soup. So big and so tasty. Sweet and sour pork. Oversize pieces of pork. A little well done but tasty.  Beef pan fried noodle with extra sauce on the side. Also tasty.  White rice and mango pudding were added at no extra charge. Sweet creamy sauce over the mango pudding. 

Service was five stars. Our waitress was warm, nice and had a great sense of humor.Prices were reasonable. A good bargain and value. 

Bathrooms also get five stars. They had to be the cleanest bathrooms that I have seen in any restaurant in a long time. 

Restaurant was large and roomy. No cramped space at all. Also convenient, as it is along the "N" light rail line. 

This is a recommendation to eat there. It is good in all respects. 

I heard that it is closed on Tuesday.
author: Steven G.

description:
This is one of the better Cantonese restaurants my family goes to.  It is definitely cleaner, and the food is pretty damn good.  Besides that, there's nothing special about this place.  The flamboyant owner aka "boss lady" adorned in gaudy jewelry and heavy makeup runs the show here, seating people, taking orders and running the register.  Her minions do all the dirty work setting up tables, bussing and serving food.  She's quite pleasant and friendly, but watch out if you are a larger party with a reservation (according to previous reviewers).  She will gladly give your table away to walk-ins if your entire party isn't present.  Yup- even if there is one straggler trying to park.

The establishment has no sense of decor other than the bare minimum.  In fact, you are greeted with three carts with restaurant stuff stored on top at the front door, which take up the perfect amount of space for seating those who have to wait for tables.  Why make the customer comfortable by taking up this precious storage space??  Let 'em stand outside in the cold.  They're going to eventually come in and spend their money anyways.  Those carts fit perfectly there!

That is all.  You come here for the food.  It's yummy and has dirt cheap prices.  I'm sure I will end up here again with the family, but I'd never go out of my way to come here.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Decided to order take out from Yan Yan since they are so close to y house and with Outside Lands everything seemed so busy on Irving. I am glad I did!

I ordered spare ribs and walnut prawns for just $20 total with tax

Wow huge portions and the walnut prawns were prefect. Not too much mayo and the walnuts were glazed and freshly crisped

Spare ribs were pretty good but I got to admit the portions were so big I kinda got tired from eating so much meat that I had plenty of leftovers for the next night

The sweet energetic lady who was dressed all in white was super friendly and nice. I assume she's the owner?

Will definitely come here again for dinner!

:)
author: Carol Y.

description:
This place is very dissimilar to a lot of other Chinese restaurants. It's clearly family/friend-owned, and there's only one hostess/waitress. Everyone else seems to be a server/busboy. You're going to have to flag down the only waitress/hostess, btw, but the food is pretty solid (they have frog, that's how you know it's for locals). I mean, everything is in Chinese, that's how you know you're in the right place.

Ambiance? None. Dirty floors and such, like all good Chinese restaurants. A couple of tvs (did I mention this place is a converted home; so good). It's a seafood restaurant, so go for the seafood. Wok-fried crab and shrimp aren't bad at all. The people working here really are characters, but they're working hard all day. Good times.
author: Danny C.

description: Came here for the very 1st time and my family & I enjoyed the food here.  Dishes were served in LARGE portions and the prices were very reasonable.  The highlight was that they offered 5 different kinds of desserts to choose from -- for FREE!!! The service can be better - you really have to grab their attention.  The boss lady was very nice.  They should renovate their restaurant -- the set-up is kind of weird.  Parking is quite challenging though. We will be back to try more dishes!!!
author: Princess B.

description:
Huge portions for an awesome price! 

It's a small place, but we went during off-hours and it was pretty empty. We weren't seated immediately so we grabbed a couple of menus and seated ourselves. However, all was quickly forgiven when Boss Lady comes over, greets us with a big HAPPY CHINESE NEW YEAR, and happily takes our order. She really makes you feel at home ;D

Free fong jao (chicken feet) and soup. Both delish! I ordered the tomato beef pan fried noodles. It was more like sweet and sour sauce beef pan fried noodles, but I didn't really mind. It was tasty and I seriously didn't even make a dent in the huge portion that was given. Boyfriend ordered the minced beef fried rice. Ditto on the no-dent-huge-portion deal. 

Ended our meal with free mango pudding and turtle shell jello. I ordered the turtle shell jello because I was curious about what it was. They give you this honey/ginger sweetener...USE IT. It makes it taste amazing. 

Boss Lady checked up on us once in the middle of the meal and again when we were leaving. 

So overall:

- Huge portions
- Awesome price
- Appetizers and dessert included
- Lovely Boss Lady
author: Chloe T.

description:
Delicious, friendly and fast! (AND CHEAP!)

Enjoyed the Honey Walnut Prawns and Garlic Fried Chicken. The hostess and servers were quick and kind. 

The servings were huge and cheap. I had enough to share with my roommate and had lunch the next day. 

I love the freebies: appetizer and dessert. Although I passed on the chicken feet, I loved the mango pudding. Sweet and just enough to top off the meal. Nothing tastes better than free! Next time red bean! 

The best part, it's two blocks away!
author: Celeste L.

description:
Cat, the owner is rude and Racist.

I was there yesterday, Thursday, Feb. 19, the day of the Lunar New Year to pickup food for New Year's lunch.  I was the first customer of the day, at 11:28 am to enter the restaurant for an order my Mother placed to be pickup at 11:30, and the food wasn't ready until a half an hour later.

I wished her, in Chinese, Gung Hat Fat Choy, and she was indifferent to me. She treated me worst than dog droppings, but she was nice to Chinese-Chinese people.  To make a long story short, and this was my family's favorite restaurant, we will not ever patronize that restaurant again because of Cat.

And I'm an ABC, and she is also very rude to non-Asian people. 

I learned as a young child growing up in San Francisco that before, during and after the New Year, to not be negative, to be good towards your family man.  She failed, and I let her know. Karma is Karma, and I feel sorry for her.  There's no excuse for bad behavior, and she is such a two face.

ABC's, please do not patronize Chinese businesses who discriminate against ABC's, and people who are non-Chinese, afterall, we live in the United States.  Sick of it!

What a Coward, and please do not patronize. 

Bu Hao!
author: Pendragon D.

description: The price is cheap and the portion is huge. The service is so so only because not enough waiters. If you are not in a rush, it is a great place to have Chinese food. They also serve all you can desserts free after the dinner.
author: Tom L.

description:
2 stars b/c taste wise its between average/a little below but also VERY cheap. BUT ITS ALSO RIDICULOUSLY CROWDED

Atmosphere:
my god they couldn't pack more asians in here if they tried. they squished 14 of us at a table that really should be for 10. we fit but our chairs were literally touching each other. there are also no windows but 1 hexagon shaped window. its HOT and STUFFY and its probably what china feels like. ugh. if you want comfort, this is NOT the place to be. and to no surprise, this place was REALLY loud. but what else do you expect?

Food:
The actual set menu we ordered included, soup, the appetizer plate with jellyfish and fixings, sweet and sour pork, chicken, fried crab, fish, vegetabels with mushrooms, squid scallop vegetable medley, and some noodles.

Soup -- very very bland. didn't have any flavor. we decided to put our appetizer from the jellyfish appetizer plate in the soup since it was in a vinegar sauce and that helped a lot since the appetizer was too vinegar-y and the soup was bland.

Sweet and sour pork, chicken, veggies, squid/scallop/veggies-- all average. just ok, nothing special.

Crab -- VERY WEIRDLY FRIED. it looked super fried but when you eat it, its super soft and taste weirdly sweet. like the maui onion flavor on chips, thats what it tasted like. and we weren't sure why. I ate it anyway cuz its crab and I didn't get sick or anything. but it was just strange. and not what I wanted.

The noodles -- it was off. it was also sweet and it was strange but I couldnt put my finger on it and neither could my cousins. all of us thought it tasted weird.

FREE Appetizer/Dessert: 
They also come with some soy sauce chicken feet for appetizers (free!) and all you can eat dessert. For the dessert, you can choose between the red bean soup, green bean soup, turtle jello, black seasame soup or mango pudding. of course, my cousins and i being the asian ams that we are, we choose mango pudding and all our parents chose the red bean soup or turtle jello.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
4 for food quality 
1 for atmosphere...
I guess that makes this a 3?

As many others Yelpers have noted, the noise level is out of control here.   
At 2pm on Sunday, we were seated at one of two 2-tops in the dining area to the right of the entrance.   Luckily we ordered and had been served before the 6 tables of screaming Asian families arrived.   

Before you start screaming racial inpropriety... I am Chinese.  I was raised to be QUIET when we went out to eat.  So really, there is just no reason why people have to yell at the top of their lungs in a restaurant.

We left within 10-15 minutes after being served because the volume was truly intolerable.   Food was VERY tasty, but we couldn't enjoy it or even talk without also yelling.  I told the hostess that we were leaving because of the noise.

I would probably call-in for takeout in the future.  Just couldn't see myself being tortured by this level of noise again.
author: Audrey E.

description:
The line here is longer than a normal Chinese place in the city. The wait is worth the time. The food comes out delicious and even though they might be slow on service, the food is great. 

I'll take off that one star for timing and kitchen size. I wish they had a bigger kitchen and more staff to help out but quite honestly, they were so nice and gave us so many extra appetizers & desserts for being patient that I really can't be mad. 

They have chicken feet for appetizers... WHO DOES THAT. The best part is that they are tastier than dim sum chicken feet! Perfect in texture and flavor. I'd pay for that. But why when they give them to you for FREE?
author: Marlene T.

description:
You will wait for your meal. Don't come with a big party cause you will wait. 
Actually came here for a party and pre ordered the party meal but when we got here they forgot about us and it took forever for the food. Pace of food coming from the kitchen was so slow.. It took a while.. Reservations were for 5:30p but they started to bring food out at 7:30.  Doesn't look very promising when the highlight was the chicken feet..  The rest of the food came out at a good pace.. There is room for improvement. 
The seafood soup was a bit thick. I had to dilute with water. Lobster was a bit over battered. Slight fishy taste and not of lobster.. Poached Chicken with ginger and garlic oil was super.. Could eat a bit plate of that.  Noodles were a bit oily.. Had a nice puddle of oil on my plate.. 

This was a good effort and it's worthy of another try..
author: Kiel V.

description:
while i've eaten here and yes, the food is not bad and price is good.  but if you have made a reservation, do yourself a favor and call back more than once to confirm.  we made a chinese new year group dinner reservation over 2 weeks ago but had to cancel and called 2 days before to be asked "you made a reservation?  when?"  

yeah....we are not going.
author: Food Is L.

description:
This is go to Chinese restaurant, which is conveniently located near my house. The wait is not that bad and they have a decent amount of space. The food here is very cheap, but the quality is good. The owner is very nice, but can sometimes be pushy. I love how our party is able to get free soup, chicken feet, and dessert for free. And all of them are great. I especially like the Efu noodles and the chicken here. The noodles have great flavor and are not that salty. Perfectly seasoned! The fried sweet and sour chicken comes out hot. However, the sauce is delicious and the chicken is great as well.

All of the desserts are great. I personally am not a fan of dessert soups, but all my family members seem to enjoy them. This is no exception. This restaurant allows you to chose the specified desert, such as red bean, sesame, or mango pudding. Also the owner may give younger children fruit jelly.

The service lacks speed. However the food makes up for the bad quality service. The food comes out fast but ordering and getting the waiter's attention is a hard job. -_-

With a party of 6, our bill totaled to under $50. This is a great price considering the amount of food we were able to bring home. Keep in mind, the soup chicken feet and desert are FREE. We left the restaurant full and satisfied. We will be coming back soon.
author: Jessica E.

description: Great for the price and portion. Dishes taste not bad as well. Mr Boss is very friendly. This place is my usually "go to".
author: Yan L.

description: My father has been a Chinese food connoisseur for the last 85 years, and he repeatedly eats here.  And so do I. Ok, I think that sums it all up!
author: Connie W.

description:
Much like many other veterans of this restaurant, the prices have been going up recently, but you can remedy and justify that price tag on their unlimited dessert and chicken feet appetizer. 

I've been coming here since I was a kid and ownership has been tossed back and forth, but I think this time around, they've struck a homerun. The new owner really knows her customers and is extremity accommodating and friendly, traits that you rarely ever see in crowded and just Chinese restaurants nowadays.

The food is very homey and the menu see ms to fit both casual diners of 2 or huge parties. My favorite is the walnut and prawns special. This is a staple in most Chinese restaurants and this place makes them quite well. I opt for less mayo because they put a bit more for my taste. During special occasions, my family orders a huge crab for the table, but for 35 bucks and only getting 1 crab per order, it's gotta be pretty darn special.

As for dessert, if you read the other reviews for this place about unlimited dessert, they weren't kidding. You can order as much as you want (as long as it's reasonable) and even take some home before you leave. 

This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco and coming here gets me excited everyone. I'm always bringing friends and family here whenever they come and visit the city. Here's to many more years of success !
author: George Z.

description:
The sweet owner is back. She makes this place go. Other servers are average at best. The prices are good, especially if you have a large group and order off the banquet family menu.

Tonight we got the $148 dinner. There were 10 of us but the food portions were so large, it could easily feed 12. 

Dishes range from good to vey good to ok. Here are some of the dishes:
Cold appetizer plate
House special chicken
Fried crab
Crispy flounder
Gai choy with mushroom
Seafood vegetable 
Walnut prawns
Peking spareribs
Seafood soup
Choice of dessert.

My favorite tonight was the crab. The flounder was too greasy. The appetizer plate was good. The prawns were a bit uneven, some of the pieces were good while some had globs of mayo. 

So lots of food right? And for $15 per person (not including tax/tip)? That's a pretty good deal.
author: Dom L.

description:
WOW! GREAT FOOD . . . GREAT CROWDS!  Another place for cheap eats.

So we've heard about this place for a long time and finally getting here for dinnner . . . on a Sunday of all days. This place is very typical Cantonese style.  We had the pork chops 50/50 fried, and in sweet/sour sauce; broccoli beef; clams in black bean sauce; beef cubes and sting beans.  The chicken feet appitizer comes first, of which those of you who haven't grown up on this may find it wierd.  But what the heck.

The food is abundant and tasty. Nothing was too salty or starchy, and I don't think they use MSG since I didn't have a food attack.  There was plenty of left-overs.

But you can't make a reservation and I didn't see any takeout. Either come at 5:30 pm or be prepared for a wait.  

HINT:  We waited 40 minutes for a table but while waiting, our order was taken.  What was really cool was that just after the chicken feet arrived, the rest of our dinner arrived within 10 minutes, hot and fresh.  I double checked the exits since the place is really crowded just in case.  Enjoy your meal.
author: Stefan L.

description: The food quality has diminished terribly. Still huge portions but of mediocre food, over fried, bland sauces even the noodles were flavorless. I used to love getting lunch from here but the chicken, beef and prawns are dry and almost inedible now. I'm sad my once favorite place is now just another hole in the wall with poor quality food.
author: Athena K.

description:
So the nice lady old owner came back!!!!! =D My aunt got to know the news of old owner took over the ownership again last week when she was buying veggies in the Chinese markets on Irving street.... I know...the previous owner did a bad job but I am so happy to know that the old owner came back!!

So I came back here today for my mom's birthday! The restaurant was packed on a Tuesday night.....I guess many old customers like me are very excited about the change in ownership! I love the cute chinese pretty lady owner =) I talked to her and she told me that they reopen the restaurant 6 days ago. 

Tonight I ordered stuff that I used to loved before
1) Deep fried pigeon (2) ~~ Super good! Flavorful but not too dry!!
2) Sauteed crab with ginger and green onions~ Fresh crab...so yummy!
3) Hand teared chicken?/ ( Sau Si Gai)~~ So so good...and it is made with chinese "yellow feathers" chicken!! it tast way better than the farm raise chicken...yum yum! Sorry..I hate foster farm chicken.....they do not taste like "real" chicken
4) Seafood and tofu clay pot~~ Is ok...can be better =)
5) Stir fried "Ong Choi" ~~ Good....
6) E-Mien Noodle with mushroom~ Good~~

!!!!! It taste just the same like it was before!!!!! Everything was so good! I am glad that the old owner is back...and for all these? It cost me only $89!!!!! (not including tips)... Not bad at all huh? =)
author: Debbie K.

description:
Becoming a regular here! I am growing to like this restaurant more and more every time my family chooses to eat here. We have ordered a banquet the past two times that we have come here and it is super delicious and very very filling!

Cold Combo, Shark fin soup, Honey Walnut Prawns, BBQ Short Ribs, Boiled Chicken, Scallops/Fish/Veggie Dish, Fried Fish with Broccoli, Abalone with Cabbage, Fried Rice, and Fried Lobster. I love the BBQ Short RIbs! My favorite out of all the dishes!

1. Cold Combo - Delicious; Full of different things, each very tasty.

2. Shark Fin Soup - Delicious; I choose to add tons of pepper, makes it a little spicier!

3. Honey Walnut Prawns - Delicious! Not so sweet prawns and super crisp and sweet walnuts. The Fried rice noodles are tasty also.

4. BBQ Short Ribs - I love this one! A little salty, but the sauce and the nuts on top make this my all time favorite of the banquet.

5. Boiled Chicken - Not the best....has some hidden bones in the back of the chicken. Garlic sauce makes it taste a lot better.

6. Scallop/Fish/Veggie Dish - Not so much a fan of the seafood on this plate, but the veggies are the best here! Snow peas, celery and the carrots! Yum!

7. Fried Fish w/ Broccoli - Not much fish to eat but the few pieces of fish that they place on top of the shell of the fish. The broccoli was my favorite part. I tried the skin of the fish, but did not really like it since it's practically bone filled and not very easy to eat (if edible at all...)

8.  Abalone w/ Cabbages - Delicious; another favorite. The abalone is nice and easy to eat and the cabbage is probably my favorite part of this dish.

9. Fried Rice - Not bad, a little greasy for my taste but good nonetheless.

10. Fried Lobster - Good but prefer regular steamed/quick stir fry lobster. The fried lobster was hard to eat and I felt that the amount of lobster meat could have been more if not fried.

11. Dessert - Same little paper to order desserts from. I chose the Turtle Shell again since I can't get it anywhere else. I really need to try something else. I like it but this time was especially bitter. Want to try the mango pudding or green bean? dessert next time.

I give the banquet an A. I really enjoy eating it even though I am stuffed to the max after visiting Yan Yan's. Can't wait to come back for more BBQ Short RIbs! :)
author: Alex T.

description:
comment applies to Lunch hours only----No more complimentary soup offered. The lady boss acts solo in taking orders and her helpers don't  show up until 12:30PM, an hour after it opens, perhaps to save labor costs. Complimentary Mango pudding is not all you can eat and the helper will always short change your order.

Finally, it no longer accepts credit card.

Overall food quality is good but service is extremely slow and poor. You must have the patience and space time to hang around to get served.



.
author: Honest E.

description: Been sitting here for one hour for the food. Been here since 5:50p now it's 7:08p.  Beware it's cash only for $300 dinner !!!
author: James Z.

description: Yan Yan opens at 11:00 AM for lunch but they don't actually start table service until 11:30 AM. They've cut back on the free chicken feet appetizers and desserts. We were given 2-3 chunks of the chicken feet per person and when we asked for a few more, the waitress had to get permission from the boss lady. Either Guillinggao or mango pudding was offered per person for dessert ... Overall food was good, not too much MSG but cutting back on what made them special won't make them standout as much anymore as there are other restaurants just as good but better value wise, like Empero Taste or Emperor Palace.
author: Harry L.

description:
Very yummy food and they're so nice with service! The waitress is the best. Always trying to talk to us and make sure we're having a good time.
Got free desserts because my family was indecisive on what to get so the lady brought us extras of each so we could all try it out.

Plates are big!!! and their deal for the family dinners are worth it!
author: Donna C.

description:
A great local Chinese restaurant in my neighborhood! My family and I ordered the dinner set for 4 last night, which included Egg Drop Soup, Clams, Fried Shrimp, Crab, Mustard Greens, and Sweet and Sour Spare Ribs.

The food was very good - might be the best spare ribs I've had so far, but the service is meh. It took awhile to have the waitress/owner take our order, and it took even longer for our food to come out, but once it did, yummmmm! Portions are plentiful and I had enough for leftovers for lunch. This place also gets really packed and LOUD - to the point that you have to start yelling just to be heard. 

I love all the desserts they have - the Mango Pudding is my favorite!
author: Cynthia L.

description: Okay, this place is really a hole in the wall. It's not a cozy place to eat at, which is why I only order take out from here. But, the owner is super friendly, the food is pretty good, and the price is fair. I loved their fried chicken and singapore noodles.
author: Casey W.

description: Food comes in big portions and it is relatively inexpensive compared to others similar restaurants. We went on a Saturday night and it was packed with long lines. Service was horrible as they took forever to take our orders and kept telling us that they are busy with not enough staff.  Once we ordered, it took another long waiting time for the food to come out. We were there for four hours from beginning to end. That's how long everything took!
author: Melissa C.

description: Made reservation for party of 8 at 5PM on Mother's Day. Shows up at 5PM, restaurant was not opened, but their sign neon said OPEN. And there is line of people waiting outside. Open their door at 5:20PM, let us and 3 other groups of people in, They gave their menus out to 3 other groups, but not us. 5:30PM, finally got our menu and pots of tea and hot water. Decided the menu sets were not good value, so we wrote down the item codes from THEIR menu of each dishes we wanted to ordered. Took couple of tries to get the waitress' attention to take our order. She saw the item codes that we wrote down and she said that was good enough. 6PM, waitress came back to us saying the cook needed the actual name of each dishes and not the the item code from THEIR menu. Oh yea, she only understand Chinese, so I had look up their item code on their menu and tell which of dishes we wanted to order. 6:45PM, we notice that they started to serve soup to people that came in and order later than we did. Owner and waitress ignore our complains at first and later said there was mix up in the kitchen. 7PM(2 HOURS later), we walk out place with no more patience for their excuses and ended up eating at another place couple block away with only 15 minute of wait for our food.
author: David Y.

description:
The portions are huge and the salt and pepper chicken wings are delicious and the best in the City bar none.

The food is great and I can't say anything negative about this restaurant. The parking in the neighborhood is tough though I must admit.

Whenever I'm on Judah, this is my place for good eats!!!
author: Gangsta G.

description: Sat down at this restaurant 1 hour ago and STILL NO FOOD. They sat us in a separate room and have come in twice to give us tea (30 min in, after some prompting) and chicken feet appetizers (1 hour in). Each time the female server has come in, she had given us the stink eye. We have had to go out and order our food, ask them about our food... About 5 times now. We are about get up and leave....
author: Alice C.

description:
MMMM Found my local Chinese spot.

Salt & Pepper Pork Chops
Honey Walnut Prawns
Shredded Scallop & Egg White Fried Rice
author: Grace T.

description:
3.5 stars. Btw I perused yelp to see what to order but wasn't too impressed with my choices.
 
What makes this restaurant and did impress me was:
(1) Complimentary soup, legit soy-sauce chicken feet, and dessert- mhmm I can eat mago pudding and sesame paste "tong sui" all day long..
(2) Boss lady's fancy get-up, which looks out of place in a typical decor SF Chinese restaurant.  She has full on makeup, jewlery, and pristine outfit like a Chinese tv show hostess with the charisma, plus she runs around taking orders and serving people. 
(3) Portions are sufficient, big, even though price is average or for some a little pricier than some Chinese restaurants.

Food- I'm Chinese so I get picky about my Chinese food:
Walnut Shrimp- Shrimp quality is on par, big and fresh and walnuts are crispy but the shrimps are not fried with enough batter and just slobbered on mayo. 3/5

Minced Chicken and stuff in Lettuce Wrap- Can't go wrong with this and the flavoring/texture is okay with chunks of chicken. The lettuce head is big and fresh. 3.5/5

Chive Noodles w mushroom- Chives are supposed to make the dish and they have flavor but not enough,  doesn't translate to the noodles. My mom makes it better. Burn. Average. 2.5/5

Fried Chicken Wings with tangy spicy sauce- which someone compared to San Tung's chicken. The sauce needs work and more heat; it's more a blob goo tangy sauce than a slather w spices... but they know how to fry chicken.  It's tender meat yet crispy through and through with the right crunch and no sogginess with the sauce. San tung chicken is a 5 in my book; this is a 3.5/5

Service is nice but slow, a lull between waiting for next dish to be served but I'll come back for complimentary chicken feet and dessert and to try the peking spare ribs and pulled (hand teared) yellow chicken salad.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Decent prices if you want chinese food with a large menu to select from. Can get pretty busy on most Friday/Sat nights.
author: Xtina W.

description: A bit on the expensive side for the same-style menus and dishes offered at other Chinese restaurants. For example, their $63 family-style meal packet would cost no more than $48 at another restaurant. The quality of the food wasn't anything spectacular. One cool thing was the complimentary cold-served chicken feet and Chinese desserts. The atmosphere in this restaurant is a bit odd and different from most other Chinese restaurants. I have tried many different Chinese restaurants, but I would not come back to this one.
author: Jackie B.

description:
Our favorite Chinese restaurant!
The owner is very friendly and sweet! Good customer service.

We usually order..

* Salty shredded chicken
* Minced squab w/ lettuce wrap
* Fish maw soup w/ yellow chive
* Special soy sauce fried noodle
* Black mushroom, water chestnuts, snow. Peas

Their foods are yummy and fresh.
We also like their dessert and chicken feet.
author: M T.

description: Well, wouldn't I know it...I had a craving for San Tung for dinner take out, and it was closed...on a Wednesday.  Here is where my Yelp research did come in handy.  I search for 'fried chicken wings' on Irving, filtered it by 'best rated' and THIS restaurant on Judah popped up.  Good enough, and so I call.  I get there and my food is ready -- 2 orders of fried chicken wings, chow mein with shrimp & spinach only, and an order of their beef short ribs.  I get home and the hubby is like these are really good fried chicken wings, and so was the rest!  DEFINITELY coming back for more take out orders!
author: Emy B.

description:
