It really doesn't matter what is written about this place because most of the older Chinese customers that frequent this place don't read Yelp. So yes, this review will also be irrelevant to those customers.

First of all, you should know that finding parking is very difficult in this area. This old restaurant looks fairly clean (at least better than most hole-in-the-wall places). They have a menu in English, but all the specials are posted in Chinese in a very unique way. They use foam-board rectangles connected with metal rings, and organized in columns by category. See my pic here: http://static1.px.yelp.com/bphoto/zgEwluViDjs382ZmKRa1Og/l

From my few experiences dining here (invited by family and friends), the specials are usually better than almost anything in the regular menu. Many of the simple stir-fry dishes were subpar, while the more complex dishes were really good (ie. beef medallions with honey, steamed fish special, etc.). Does that mean that I would dine here often or recommend it to others? no. 

Why? Because this is the only Chinese restaurant in SF, where I had to wait +45 minutes before our table got any food (that's time seated at the table, not time waiting outside). That's embarrassing for a host and his/her dinner guests. We didn't even get an apology. Yes, the place was busy that day, all tables booked. We had reservations, dining banquet-style, so they knew we were coming. A good Chinese restaurant would have managed to serve at least the appetizer, or the soup, or the waiter could have brought some peanuts.

For me that's like breaking an unwritten rule. In a good Chinese restaurant, you don't leave hungry (unless the food is really bad), AND after placing your order, you NEVER have to wait a very long time without any food. There could be delays between plates, but getting nothing for any time over 20-30 minutes is unacceptable. I don't patronize Chinese restaurants that break those rules. If I get invited by a friend or family I'll go, I just won't come back here when I'm paying.

The reason why I'm giving it 3 stars instead of 2, is because I respect that some friends of family like this place.
author: Luis C.

description:
OMG, their food are so good although it doesn't look anything like it from the outside. Me and my friends went there for dinner and we love everything we ordered. The free starter, chicken claws, were great. We ordered the deep fried pigeons, they were juicy and done just right. Another great dish we ordered was the snails in hot chili sauce, it was soooo good. My friend who doesn't eat spicy food also can't resist them. Last but not least was their fre dessert and I chose the green bean paste. I can totally tell they made the green bean paste themselves because it's so different from the ones you could eat from other chinese restaurants. 

Overall, I would say this place is super awesome and should be a must go place when visiting SF!!!
author: Katie C.

description:
Time to update the review I posted 8 month ago, which was only about take out.

Country cooking here.  The food preparation is consistent. Ingredients are fresh.  Not a bad dish at any of the several dinners and lunches that we've had here.

This is a good place to go for everyday meals.   It's a ok for groups, too.   However, go elsewhere, if you're looking for festive Chinese fare.  No sticky rice chicken, here.

You can get one of the best Hung Toa Yee Foo won ton here.  The won ton is still slightly crispy when the it is served.

It's a small place that can get crowded. The dining room is not managed well to accommodate reservations, at times.

I still won't get take out from here. Portions are not the same as when you dine-in.  Same price, too.
author: Debbie T.

description: Every time I come here, It takes 1 hour to order and get my food. Food quality is great, but by that time, I'm super pissed off and have no appetite. And what is so irritating is when half the restaurant is empty, and you come when the restaurant opens at 5pm!
author: Eric C.

description:
We had a late mother's day celebration and my sister picked this place. Afterall, this place was the go-to-place for family gatherings, birthday celebrations, and holiday dinners.

Tuesday Night

Bear in mind
1) the location of this restaurant and the ridiculous time it takes to find parking. 
2) the common setting of Chinese restaurant tables (if you don't know, they are foldable and extendable) 
3) There were AT LEAST 6 empty tables with NO RSVP 

So, we made reservation for a party of 5 at 6:30. We told the owner our party was actually going to be 6 and she said "that's okay, but wait for whole party to come before I put a table together for you". (What's funny is, when we had reservations for a party of 20, that rule was not implemented, nor did it even exist.). 

Okay fine .. since my family and I are considerate patrons, we stood outside, in the wind, because we didn't want to block her doorway.

About 10 minutes later, we told her "the fifth person is parking, can you seat us?" The owner replies " wait for her to come then I put table together for you"

Okay, fine .. Immediately after finishing her sentence, she seats other walk-in customers, who did not have their complete party present....

Our fifth person arrives, and we tell her "she's here". Lady replies "wait for sixth person, then I put table together for you"

Then again .. more customers walk in to get seated when the rest of their party is looking for parking.

Seriously, WTF. Do you think your restaurant is the new Five Star Fine Dining joint in San Francisco? Unless you have a fancy smancy bar area for customers to lounge around and wait for the rest of their party, you have no right telling your customers to wait outside for the rest of their party. Oh, but then again, OTHER CUSTOMERS were seated immediately after they kissed ass and chanted "boss lady"

Dude, I lived in China for 4 months and COMMUNISTS CHINESE PEOPLE HAVE BETTER SERVICE THAN YOU. You, my dear, have a lot of reviewing to do. Maybe some CUSTOMER SERVICE 101 will help you, but then again, I think all these good reviews on yelp ABOUT YOUR FOOD has clouded your judgement on what customer service is. 

What-a-damn-shame ... I personally wanted to give you 0 stars, but that hasn't been made possible, yet.

Now, I will pray for forgiveness for writing such a harsh review. Wait, but then again this was factual and is backed up by my sister.
author: Brenda C.

description:
I've always been impartial to this place since it's the default go-to place for family reunions, gatherings, birthdays, etc. So last Tuesday, I made reservations for 5 people at 6:30 PM and the lady, whom I was later informed owned the place, told me it was fine. Around 5, I called back to ask her if it would be ok to change the party to 6 and again, she said it was fine.

All seemed to be well and dandy until we actually got there. 
Things to note:
1. Restaurant is in a residential area so parking after 6 pm may be difficult
2. SF weather any time after sun set  especially in the SUNSET is going to be CHILLY. (will be referred back to shortly)

Upon arrival at 6:20 pm, I noted that over half the restaurant was empty. We informed the hostess (owner) that 4 out of the 6 people in our party was here. She told us that when the rest of our party arrived, she would seat us... which under normal circumstances would have been fine, BUT as we stood outside of the entrance freezing to death, we couldn't help but notice several groups of people going in and being seated with other party members that were THERE already. OUTRAGEOUS RIGHT?

When our fifth member arrived, we promptly asked to be seated since the last remaining person was finding parking. Again, she said that she would seat us when EVERYONE in our party was present. ARE YOU SERIOUS LADY?

1. This policy doesn't seem to be applicable to everyone else you have already seated.
2. The restaurant is half empty, doesn't look like a whole crowd will suddenly bombard your place, so I highly doubt seating the 5 of us now versus 6 will really make a difference for your business.
3. WHERE IS YOUR HUMANITY? It's freezing and we have already explained to you the LAST PERSON is already HERE but trying to look for parking.
4. You are not a 5 star or even a 4 star restarant. You don't even have a waiting area for guests to wait at.  Your food isn't even extraordinary so WHERE IS YOUR SENSE OF CUSTOMER SERVICE??

Needless to say, we just told her our whole party was here, but we're just going to bring business to somewhere else FOREVER. I would totally give this place a ZERO star for the complete lack of customer service if yelp had that feature, but word of advice, head on down to EIGHT IMMORTALS on Taraval and 24th if you're looking for good chinese food & great customer service.
author: Ada C.

description:
This is my go to place for fried salt and pepper wings. Considering taste and price, it's the best wings you can get hands down.

I usually order a tray of them (5 lbs @ $4 per lbs) for $22 including tax but when I called in my order today, they told me it's $30 ($5.50 per lbs) now. I told them that I've order it many times for $22. They said they just changed owners and prices have gone up but they will just charge me $25 (including tax). That is a hopeful sign of good service with new management but hopefully they will set that as their permanent price or else I will have to start ordering elsewhere.
author: Andy W.

description:
The restaurant had a makeover since the last time we ate there which I believe was about three years ago.  The place is much brighter and cleaner.  One thing though, the lady who works behind the cash register, who appears to be the owner or manager is not friendly.  She had an attitude.  

I do admit that their free range chicken with ginger sauce and their chicken and corn soup were delicious.   Both items had just the right amount of seasoning and very tasty. 

The sweet and sour pork was not that good.  The meat was not crispy the way I like it.  The sauce had more vinegar taste to it.
author: J W.

description: Worst service ever. The food is nasty and cold. This place looks like a junk yard. Not a pleasant place to eat.
author: Danny Zhi W.

description:
Like every Daniel Day Lewis film appearance or a Kevin Durant invasion of Rucker Park, Yan Yan's hostess/owner charismatically steals the show with her gaudy outfit (emerald suit), pointed menu advice, constant follow up, and persistent offers of unlimited complimentary desserts. 

She commanded our attention upon insisting we replace an ordered dish - hardly anybody would provide an honest appraisal of what to avoid at their own restaurant! Her chiding banter when one of our friends stubbornly refused to taste the house soup and unprompted provision of additional desserts after seeing another friend ferociously devour his successfully created a comfortable, homey dining atmosphere, where we gladly welcomed her interactions with our table.

Some memorable dishes include the spice-laden, battered Dry-Fried Crab copiously drizzled with green onion slivers, faultless sweetly glazed Honey Walnut Prawns painted only lightly with mayo, and crispy Fried Fish steeped in a rich, creamy corn gravy.

Peek in to confirm the owner is present before committing to dine at Yan Yan's to ensure being taken care of!
author: Andrew M.

description:
Parking isn't easy to find, and you definitely need to be acquainted with the owner (boss lady). 
Food is pretty good and cheap for what I've found in San Francisco.

TWO WORDS: unlimited desert.
Save room, they've got your typical red and green bean soups, but they've also got MANGO PUDDING, SEASAME DESSERT, AND HERBAL GRASS JELLY!
author: Maggie L.

description: The boss lady is fierce. She was mopping the floor when I came in so you know she gets down to business. The chicken wings were so crispy! You get a choice of free dessert. Will definitely come back to try other items on the menu.
author: Sophia C.

description: Servers are very mean, and we also waiting for a long time. Nobody service us. The only person can take order is the boss. She was very busy all the time. I don't recommend anyone come here.
author: Jacob H.

description: The food came out a little slow, but it was because they wanted everything to come at once. The food itself was very good, not too salty and not bland. The best part was they let us choose our own desserts and I got to try three different ones.
author: Victor C.

description:
The Chinese restaurants in the Sunset area are all mediocre.  This one is probably one of the better ones with decent prices.  But I have only done Take-Out here. I'm sure if I ate there the food will be better.   

I ordered the Dry Fried Fish Fillet - Good but the breading was a little too thick for my preference.  But the sweetened soy sauce that came with it for dipping was really good. The Honey Walnut Prawns was decent...tho a little too much mayo but the portion was good.  The Ying Yang Spare Ribs needs improvement.  It's 1/2 Peking sauce and 1/2 Salt n Pepper.  This dish was bland overall despite the sauces and jalapenos. And it needs to be crispier.  It probably got a little mushy from the heat as I did take out. 

Overall it's 3 stars for the food.  But giving it an extra star because they give out complimentary dessert for take out too.  I got the sesame paste/soup and the herbal grass jelly w/ ginger syrup.  Both very good!  But make sure you request for it!
author: Cathy M.

description:
Yan Yan is so cheap! 3 meals for less than $25. We had a mushroom and watercress dish. The mushrooms were so good but the watercress was gross. We also had a seafood soup that was not so great, not enough flavor. But the chicken and eggplant in clay pot was the winner. So warm, tasty and smothered in a delicious gravy. One weird thing is that they had shark fin all over the menu, which is illegal. Well it's illegal as of the first of 2013. But still it's endangered, so yeah.

Unfortunately, I wasn't very taken with the restaurant. From the outside it didn't even look like an eating establishment, they put minimal effort into decor, and someone decided to clean the floor with bleach during our meal. Not cool. Basically, the restaurant is gross and the food is good.
author: Kristen F.

description: OK. This is my CHINESE family's FAVORITE GO TO CHINESE RESTAURANT in all of San Francisco. I checked in over 11 times so that should say something. My family and I come here almost once a month. I suggest you call in and reserve a table because the wait can be hella long. Plus sometimes when you call the day of, they might not even have any tables for reservation anymore! So heads up! I love love love this place!
author: Ruhjeenuh Z.

description: Went here for Mother's Day dinner. This place looks small from the outside but they have a private room in the back. Good is passing the time, it wasn't as good as the first time I went but considering it was Mother's Day I'll let it go. The owner of manager was really nice, she took our orders and the food came fairly quick. She gave us some suggestions and we asked about crab and she told us her honest opinion that it wasn't worth it cause the price were really high. At the end of your dinner they even give you dessert and I don't mean oranges. You get to choose from a bunch like mango pudding, red bean, etc and you can have as many as you want! My sons bday was coming up and she heard us and gave him the whole thing of the Asian jelly tub. Kuddos for this place
author: Hoa T.

description: Friendliness welcomes you.  Yes, the hostess is so memorable.  I'll start with the dessert.  Wow, a choice of desserts?  are you kidding?  Mango pudding, Turtle pudding (no turtle was harmed), sesame pudding, and whatever she said.  We had the sweet and sour chicken, crunch, crunch.  The salted egg fried squash is perfection.  If you are a salty egg person, you got to order this.  I don't see it on the menu, maybe it is a secret for those who have eaten it here.  The shredded sesame chicken, forget about the mayonnaise, just a natural taste of chicken and sesame flavor.  Three dishes get the Oscar for Oscar night.  The service was very attentive.  Need more people to join dinner so that we can taste more than 3 dishes.  They have complimentary drunken chicken legs.  Chewy and tasty.  Excellent dinner indeed.
author: Helen L.

description: The price is definitely good, but I must say the quality was okay.   Many of the dishes we wanted they were out and both my parents and I agreed that the taste was lacking.   The owner was very nice and insisted on giving us extra desserts as we were leaving, so I give them a lot of credit for customer service, but if I go back, maybe we'll consider the set menu.  That's what it seemed like all the bigger tables got.   Waitress was very nice as well.   Very chatty.
author: Edgar C.

description:
While the food is decent, the service was horrible.  First, the first food came in super late.  Secondly, everything was mixed up.  We got chicken first, some other plates, THEN appetizers, then everything came up at the same time.  Third, one of the dishes had scallops and they went REALLY bad.  Being a seafood restaurant, they need to make sure their seafood is fresh!

2 stars, plus 1 more cuz it was dirt cheap.  We had tons of food for 13 people, and it came out to like only $20 per person.
author: Alan C.

description: Hard to find street parking around the area.  DON'T COME ON A BUSY DAY! We came on memorial day and the service was absolutely terrible. They get super overwhelmed and you're going to have to wait a long time for your food. Originally we were going to pick out specific dishes, but they suggested we pick from their set meal packages, ie dinner for 8, dinner for 10 etc as they were too busy.  Also, if you have any elderly/handicapped diners, make sure you let them know that way they don't put you in their back room which has 3 steps you have to climb up.  My 92 year old grandmother, and another handicapped person on adjacent table was unaware of this...Good luck getting up those steps without help.  Also, the waiters aren't going to want to service you as the location in the back is too hard to get into.  As for the food, I thought it was subpar.  Maybe when you come at a less busy time, it may be better.  One of the dishes ordered was the seafood lettuce wrap which surprisingly enough had no seafood in it, I think they maybe used hoi sin sauce and call it seafood??? We had a party of 11 and the dish came with 6 pieces of lettuce.  When asked for more lettuce, the response was that it was going to cost extra. Say what? How stingy are you guys that you can't provide a few extra pieces of lettuce.  Also, there were times when we had to service ourselves...Sensing our dissatisfaction, the boss lady gave us a complimentary kung pao chicken wing dish...which was the farthest thing from kung pao chicken I had ever seen. In the end, they also messed up the dessert order as we had ordered more green bean soup than red bean soup, but they mixed it up and had it the other way around.  Overall, I would say this place is not worth it. This place wasn't that cheap and it wasn't that good either.  Oh and they automatically tacked on a 15% tip (already written on bill and tabulated for you), so I guess you don't even have to even think about giving anymore than that...not that I would've given more than that since it was already decided for me. Not sure if this place will survive, if it can't even handle busy days...bad experiences will just drive people away and maybe when it's less busy the food will be better? but then they won't be making money as seats won't be filled...catch 22?  Oh and originally we made a reservation for 15 but a few couldn't make it...yea there's no way that they can fit 15 on a table even though they said they could make it happen...
author: Tom S.

description: Pretty decent for Chinese food. The owner lady is very outgoing and nice maybe it was just because they forgot a few plates but I think she's a nice person. The dishes like chow fun are a little too oily but still good every once in a while. Also the best part is dessert comes after your meal with the choice of grass jelly mango pudding or red bean soup (tong sui). It's also right next door to one more cup.
author: Laylay B.

description: The meaning of "getting a bang for your buck". It is so affordable, I am able to treat my entire family a meal here and still have 100 boxes of left overs. Yes, service can be a little slow when they're busy, but it is worth the wait. The owner looks like a Hong Kong celebrity and gives you unlimited desserts!
author: kim w.

description:
We were here to celebrate my Aunt's birthday and my nephew's graduation last night.  First, there is only street parking.  Pretty tough if you have a full size vehicle like I do.  I had to park 3 1/2 away.  This is the only negative thing I can write in my review.  

Otherwise, the food was very good and we ordered about 15 dishes.  My favorite was the salted egg deep fried crab and clams in black bean sauce.  The others were go don't get me wrong, but the crab and clams are my favorite.  The mango pudding was very good. All the dishes were prepared perfectly and no salty at all.  

They gave us free soup, chicken feet and dessert for free which was great like previous Yelpers mention.  And they are very generous on the portions.  

The owner, she was very nice and very talkative.
author: Rose F.

description: Yan Yan lost its family-budget-friendly appeal to me.  The Honey Walnut Prawn that use to be $8 is now $13.  I understand going up in prices by a dollar or two... but $5?!  That is a huge increase within a short time span.  The rest of the menu are all up there with major restaurants.  If I'm going to pay those prices, I will expect my spoons to be clean, without dry food spots, as well as a nicer decor, and spacious tables.  No more Yan Yan for me.  Sorry boss lady, but your chicken feet just doesn't justify your prices.
author: Jason L.

description: Alright, this place is so jammed packed that they are not honoring their reservations.  Its basically first come first serve even though they still take reservations.  They should changed their system and just dont take reservations rather than have the customers wait for hours outside.
author: S F.

description:
The food is absolutely delicious! We have been there for at least 4, 5 times and we're never disappointed with all the different dishes we tried.  The seasoning is distinct with every dish, not like other Chinese restaurants that season everything with soy sauce. 

The owner takes the order and she is very cheerful and helpful. She would even tell you the dish is expensive now, and suggest another cheaper substitute. And she makes it all fun and ice breaking to start a joyful meal. 

Oh, also the after dinner dessert!  They offer 5 different kinds of transitional Chinese desserts for everyone to choose. My mom enjoyed the GUI Ling GAO so much and asked if she'd have another one, the owner gave us two more for free.  

We always had a great time there and We will definitely go again!
author: Wen H.

description:
The original Yan Yan is back! 

This was my favorite Chinese restaurant in the neighborhood until it changed ownership. 

I had heard that that the old owner is back, so i went to see.  Yes, the original owner is back along with her excellent cook! 

Kat is the perfect attentive hostess and I am glad that Yan Yan has been restored to the way I have remembered and enjoyed it!
author: Steve L.

description: Our hostess was the best--super cheerful, efficient, and thoughtful! We had a great time, and the food was delicious! Can't wait to come back on my next trip to SF!
author: Vi N.

description: Food is ok. Solid 3 stars, prob will not return bc there are other excellent choices similar to this one around
author: Kathy C.

description: WARNING: NO PARKING, you have to circle the blocks over and over, and over, and over, hopping you will find street parking, good luck with that. Great neighborhood restaurant if you are in walking distant. When you enter the restaurant, you are greeted by 2 carts full of dirty dishes and trash, we stood in the small entry for about 10 minutes before the Hostess walked by, like we are invisible, we had to let her know I would like to eat at Yan Yan. 80% of the restaurants are catered to large groups, if you have a party of 4 or less, they have about only 8 tables for you, so we waited for the people at the small tables to finish eating while there was empty large tables. Here is when it starts getting comical, a table of 2 elderly Chinese couple was done eating, they even packed up leftovers, but they sat there for 10 minutes because the hostess didn't bring them their check, we stood literally right behind this table for another 10 minutes, they still waited for their check, finally, the elderly man got tired of waiting and pull out his phone and both of them started to play games on it.  After about 25 minutes, the hostess brought them the check, they paid, but now they want dessert.  The line is getting lone, and if you know anything about Chinese restaurants, people will cut in front of you, so I just threw myself on that table. A server cleaned the table for us, and then nobody ever came back, I had to go get the menus, every time I asked someone to take my order, they waved to someone else apparently, none of them speak English, so I wrote down my order on a napkin and handed to the hostess, who is also the owner. How's the food? We ordered a 2lb Chef's Special Sauce Lobster, Clams with Black Bean Sauce, Salty Shredded Chicken, Chinese Bacon with Preserved Veg, Deep Fried Squad, and Chicken with Snow Peas for the baby.  The Lobster is basically salt and peppered Lobster with minced meat and leeks, there was no "sauce", just deep fried and dried, should have order the Ginger and Scallion sauce instead. The rest of the food is just ok, your typical Chinese restaurant, nothing here really separates them apart from countless other restaurants. Everyone raved about the Deep Fried Crispy Squad (Qual), Bodega's Squad is 10 times better, they are crispy to the point that you can chew through the bones.  I kept flagging everyone down for our bill because people in line was looking at our table since we where done eating, for 15 minutes, they never brought our bill, I had to go up to the Hostess to ask for the bill and pay right there.  Overall, we wouldn't come back due to the parking situation, standard service, and average food.
author: Hieu L.

description: Updating my review since I finally finished my meal. I've been here for 2 hours 45 min and the service and food was slow. It took us 55 minutes just to get soup. Everything else came in slow intervals. After an hour and a half into our time here, our last item, crab, finally came. The food was mediocre. My family was getting cranky. Typical chinese food that yoy can find anywhere. The waitresses were purposely ignoring us. Rude. Never coming back.
author: Melody M.

description: Terrible service. We ordered more food in the middle of our meal and at first they said it was fine. Then the woman came back and said we had to leave because more people were coming in. We used to come here often before the new management came in, but won't be coming back after this.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Dropped to a "one star".

Last visit was on June 14th, 2014.  We had 7 adults and a 2-1/2 year old and a baby.  Chose it mainly because it was close.  But never again.

Now if one simply wants a huge quantity of food, then this place is OK, but the service is between fair and poor and the quality of the food is no better.  Everything was very oily and greasy.  The owner insisted that we pay with cash, and that we be there exactly at 6 PM as another party needed our table at 7:30.  However at 8 the slow staff were still serving us.  And there were empty tables.  

Not a pleasant experience.  Won't go back.
author: Bob S.

description:
Birthdays, Holiday celebrations, family reunions, and "let's just eat out" dinners are usually serviced at Yan Yan seafood restaurant. This is my dad's favorite restaurant in the world and boss lady knows it too. She is just a sweetest lady ever, always happy to see her customers and remembers her usual customers. That service alone had made us a loyal customer. 

Our usual are: 
-Hand-shredded chicken 
-Garlic pea shoot 
-Steamed rock cod or catfish w/ black bean sauce 
-Steamed shrimp w/ spicy soy sauce or crispy crab 
-Claypot (eggplants w/ salted fish and chicken) 
-Noodles or steamed rice or a fried rice 

They always give out complimentary chicken feet for appetizers and desserts to finish the meal. 

They have a really great menu and as for the pricing; everyone will think you're a genius for recommending Yan Yan for a large-party dinner.

::NOTE::
This review has been sitting in my draft for a couple of months now. Since the beginning of July, they have gone under a new management.
author: Jenny K.

description:
I would have never known about this place had my friend not invited me to her family dinner. Its location would make you think its not popular considering its hidden in the residential area of Judah. My friend's mom knows the owner and its probably a good thing otherwise we would be waiting for days!

It is a fairly sized restaurant and I believe there's also a back room We snagged three large tables and it just so happens another party was going on that snagged four family tables. Ooops for any one just coming here that night for a regular dinner:( 

We ordered the fixed menu options and added a few more dishes. My favorite was the garlic porkchop? I can't even really remember since it was a few weeks ago and now I'm not convincing you to get it but do be on the lookout for a garlic meat entree! 

I'm assuming they are well known for their yee mein. Almost all the tables got it and in my opinion, its NBD but lots of people seemed to like it. The noodles were well flavored and not too greasy, though its not meant to be greasy. 

Best part of the night is the dessert! They allow each person at the table to select one from 4 options: Mango pudding, sesame dessert, turtle pudding, and one more that I can't remember.
author: Connie C.

description:
3.5 STARS!

Been here a couple times with the family and the food is decent. It's better than some of the other Chinese restaurants there are in SF, and definitely NOT Americanized (which means all the local Sunset folks go there, not tourists)! The owner is very nice and always has a great attitude, which makes the dining experience more pleasant.

Dinner always starts off with some free marinated chicken feet, YUM! These are pretty tasty, especially since there's a hint of spiciness to it. Best of all, it's FREE! 

Typical dishes my family orders:
1) Crab 
I've tried both the egg yolk style, and the fried garlic, green onions, dry style (not sure what to call it... not the traditional stir fry crab with ginger and green onions, wet style though). The crabs are always gigantic and fresh! Flavors are good, though I think I prefer R&G Lounge...? 

2) Chicken Wings (with that sweet and mild spicy sauce, similar to San Tung)
Pretty tasty as wel, but I think I still prefer San Tung's because the ones here are the wet style, not dried. I prefer mine the San Tung way

3) Beef Strips with fried garlic
Hit or a miss. Sometimes it's good, sometimes it's too salty... 

4) Singaporean Style Noodles
Just enough kick to it, and uses lots of ingredients, unlike some places which is literally all noodles

5) Pork Chops 2 styles (Peking style, and fried)
Like the peking style more cause of the sauce, but the meat is way too tender (yes, it can be a bad thing...) It was mushy already by the time I took my first bite

Don't really remember the other dishes I've tried here, but can't complain too much about them. They are generally good, with some exceptions. Dinner ends with "home made" desserts of your choice - red bean soup, green bean soup, mango pudding, black sesame paste, that black bitter thing that looks like grass jelly. I think the prices are pretty reasonable too, and more on the inexpensive side!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Updated. It took me a while to update my reviews. The original owner came back, n I've been coming here too many times ever since. My favorites: Garlic spare ribs, Honey walnut prawn, Sweet sour fish filet, Peking spare ribs, S&P spare ribs. The lady boss is super super friendly. 

I used to be a regular customer, but the original owner left, and they changed their menu a little bit. I have only gone there once eversince. The previous owner was super friendly which was one of the reasons we kept going back for a quick dinner. But now, we can't even order our fav dish anymore either because they don't have them on menu or they taste different. We liked Garlic beef short ribs, Fried fish filet with corn gravy, Salt pepper spare ribs, Peking spare ribs.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description:
I overheard ladies talking about Yan Yan Seafood at my beauty shop, so decided to give it a try. And I'm very glad I did. I had the Chef's Special Lamb w/ leeks. It was delicious. Mango pudding was good too. 

I will try a fish dish next time.
author: Roberta O.

description:
Great place for family style dinners. Food is large portions and tastes great!

Nice little chicken feet appetizers, on the house! Variety of desserts you choose on a little check-off form, all of which are tasty! 

Boss lady takes all the ordering and even gives suggestions, all of which are not pushy towards expensive dishes! 

Parking in this area is not great at all...

PLAN AHEAD OF YOU NEED LARGE TABLES! GETS VERY BUSY HERE!
author: Kevin V.

description: Great food. Slow on the wait time but all in all the best Chinese I have had in a long time.
author: Bombiz V.

description:
Great food for the price with complementary dessert - mango pudding black sesame or red bean soup.

My favorites:
1.  Chicken salad
2.  Salted egg yok crab and/or pumpkin
3.   Yee me in
4.   Walnut prawns
author: Jennifer T.

description:
My Chinese-speaking aunt trying to order something I can eat from the hostess:

(We want to order the braised tofu & veggies dish)

"Can we do the white tofu, not fried?"
"Ok we can do steamed bean cake."
"No, she would like it stir fried with the vegetables, just use the tofu without deep-frying it."
"Ok, we can do steamed bean cake."
"Ok, fine."
"We do the steamed bean cake with dried scallops & shrimp."
"No, she is vegetarian."
"Ok, we do the steamed bean cake with dried scallops & shrimp."
"No, she is vegetarian. No meat."
"No meat? Ok, we do the steamed bean cake with dried scallops & shrimp."
"No- NO MEAT. Seafood is meat!"
"Ok, we do the steamed bean cake with just the dried scallops."
"NO! NO MEAT!" 
"Ok, we do steamed bean cake with just mushrooms."
"Ok."

SO ASIAN!!! This was worse than the My Big Fat Greek Wedding "Ok, you eat lamb" part. 

We ordered a bunch of dishes family-style, which my carnivore family seemed to enjoy. The deep fried fish, fish w/ corn sauce, beef & bell pepper, crispy chicken, etc. The bean thread noodles we ordered came with shrimp also, even though we specified it was for the vegetarian... I was eating just plain steamed rice until my bean cake topped with mushrooms came out. This was very good, & even with two ingredients it was very flavorful. I ate a bunch, until my ignorant uncle took the serving spoon from the tofu, stuck it in the beef dish, and then back in the tofu, dropping some in it in the process. Even though each dish already had its own serving spoon.  WTF. At the very end of the meal two plain veggie dishes came out. The mustard greens, & A-choy. The mustard greens weren't bad, but some were a bit bitter as expected. The A-choy had an odd taste because they used fermented soybean paste in the sauce. 

All around- NOT a pleasant or veggie-friendly experience. I realize this is a seafood restaurant, but most Asian places cater easily to vegetarian needs...
author: Kimberly A.

description: Love their salted fish fried rice.
author: Suwito S.

description: Great Chinese restaurant!! Food is not as only as other places and you get free appetizer and free dessert! The manager is really great, only downside service can be slow cause it's busy at times.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Food is decent, usually depending on what plate.

Customer service is pretty good, considering it to be a small local restaurant. The lady boss is always cheerful and nice!
author: Simon W.

description: My family is a regular here. The food is terrific, service is terrific. For some reason, my family likes to talk about how they've seen their waiters at other Chinese restaurants. I love how they let you choose your own dessert instead of just giving you the daily special, which in some restaurants, are crap. Only thing I don't like about this place is the atmosphere. It seems really depressing for some reason, maybe it's just me though.
author: Tony K.

description: Great customer service Kat is very nice and friendly and food is great!
author: Akoni L.

description:
Don't let the facade or the interior of the place fool you because you're in for some delicious and CHEAP Chinese food, oh and a very friendly boss lady. 

I had been here a long long time ago but it wasn't until sometime recently a couple of months ago when I came here with Jenny K and her parents to for a small celebration. (Thanks for re-introducing me here because I've been coming here wayyy too frequently now!)

You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. There's a whole bunch of food items written in Chinese posted on the walls, too bad there no English underneath it, but that's ok! 

After you come here a couple of times, the boss lady will surely recognize you-- something I highly admire from places I visit frequently. She's very upbeat in energy and you can see she surely enjoys what she is doing. 

My last visit here was about the time of Chinese New Year and had called in a couple days before to make reservations. The boss lady was very apologetic in that the only time she had available was at about 7:45pm noting that it was a bit late and thanked me for being understanding. We had a party of about 9 adults and the total cost of the meal was no more than $120, including tips. Yan Yan is truly a hidden gem.
author: Eugenia G.

description: I am so happy that my favorite chef and boss lady are back. This is now again my favorite restaurant!
author: Li H.

description: The hand pulled salt chicken with sesame oil is surprisingly not salty and lip smacking good!!
author: Sheue L.

description: Since the owners changed...there's no mango pudding anymore :(
author: Amanda L.

description: Salt and Pepper Squid is the best. Their portions are also huge.
author: Danielle P.

description: This is the best restaurant in san fran. Everything I ordered is delicious. I don't know how they do that. I highly recommend it. Easy 5 stars.
author: J T.

description:
The owner lady is hilarious and super friendly. It's not one of those typical Chinese restaurants, they haves pretty full range of food choices that have satisfied me in the past. I wish I wasn't such a fob and new the name of these dishes in english, I'll give it a try:

Good: salt and pepper squid, watercress cooked in "quality" soup (direct translation), braised chicken wings, crispy noodles
Probably wouldn't order again: steamed tofu with mushroom (bland)

Oh, and you get free dessert - green bean soup better than the red bean, but both are home made. Also try the coconut pudding.
author: Danica F.

description:
On a Friday night, being too sluggish to cook dinner is acceptable. Also being with your beloved family is a must.

Well, it's not a good way to start our dinner. Matt, as expected, had trouble finding parking in this busy Judah St.-strip. When we finally found parking, we still had to walk up 2 fat hills to the restaurant.

The restaurant was also crowded and the wait took nearly 30 minutes for a table for the four of us. You can easily tell that our night is off to a rough start.

When finally seated, our table was sticky as an adhesive sticker with a fishy odor and debris leftover from the previous party. 

We ordered the Steamed Bass with soy sauce, Steamed gai-lan with oyster sauce and pork spare-rib with black bean sauce. The fish is very delicate and soft to eat, although we had to work on stripping the fish meat from the scale. The gai-lan was tender and very crunchy, and the sparerib is very juicy with the meat falling apart from the bone. Our $30.00 meal came with rice, tea, red-bean soup and bland orange wedges. But other than the bland orange wedges, our meal and time at this restaurant were below-average. 

It also appears that wife is very popular at every Chinese restaurant we dined. She chats with everybody in the restaurant. 

HAND OFF, MAN; SHE'S MINE!!
author: Matt G.

description:
In town for work. Figured there would be plenty of top-shelf Asian spots. Found this one around the corner and --good sign--it was chock full of big groups speaking Chinese. Waiters flying by with HUGE plates of seafood, chicken feet, etc and all presented beautifully. I was sad I was taking out. 

Hole in the wall. Small--room for maybe 60 when full. Crabs in tanks near the register. Mostly big tables for family-style.

Salt'n'Pepper Tofu: salty (obv) but delicious with choke garlic and jalapenos. Told me 30 min and when I came back the boss lady goes, "Ohhh nooo. Your food no crispy anymore! You want I can make new and you wait?" So she quick put in another order for free and the first one was actually fine. Bonus. Nice lady.

Vegetable Seafood: got this just to see if it was a mock meat or something. Nope. Just a ton of snow peas, big shiitakes, and water chestnuts. All of which I love. In a "white" sauce. Win.

Squid in Black Bean Sauce: a slight fishy smell which means probably frozen squid, not market fresh which is to be expected for $7.95. Still really good and squid cooked perfectly.

Didn't ask for rice, didn't want it, didn't get it. All Chinese places should do that.

Everything was cheap, staff friendly. Only white person in there was me. I'd eat here a lot if I lived nearby.
author: Justin P.

description: Great place to eat. Excellent fried flounders, beef ribs, etc. Good price and portions. I would go there again with friends and family.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I rarely give out five stars to Chinese restaurants but this is one of the few that deserves it.  First off, this place isn't a high end Chinese restaurant, it serves very good basic Chinese food and at a good price.  I eaten here many times and the food has always been good and consistent.   I have to admit that not every single dish has been perfect but hey, I never been to a restaurant where every dish was perfect after multiple visits.

One thing here that separates this restaurant from other Chinese restaurant is the women who runs the show here.  You can't really miss her, she's the one that is nicely dressed and full of make-up.   All I can say is this women knows how to run a resturant, talkative, nice, and understands a customer the moment he/she walks in to her place.   This is a complete opposite from a few years back when another guy own this place, absolute dump at that time.  Too bad the boss women is stuck at this location, put her in a nice location and you can bet she'll draw you a good amount of customers just on her personality.
author: Guess G.

description:
OH FO SHO.

HELLA GOOD EGGPLANT & SALTED CHICKEN CLAYPOT! 
Plus the lady that takes down orders is hilare!!! She's the one that always has her hair up in a long ponytail (looks like it could possibly be one of those clip-on ponytail pieces).

They always give out free chickens feet and green onion pancake appetizers and free dessert options (my family always goes for the mango pudding).
author: Denise L.

description:
very tasty roasted garlic crab...BUT WAT TOO PRICEY!!....drove in to the Sunset for the crab with friends and was embarassed by the rediculously high price of the crab....39 bucks for one medium size crab!
I don't know about you but I know when I'm getting gouged.
Why???because Harrison Ford stopped in there way back when??
author: Nuria S.

description:
Great food! We live three blocks away and we never knew this gem of a restaurant. We chanced upon it tonight when my husband looked for a nearby restaurant. 

We ordered salt and pepper squid and beef with vegetable (chinese broccoli and carrots). Called in for our order and the wait was 45mins. Worth it though. Hubby picked up the food and he immediately bbm'd me that we have found a new go-to place for good food. The restaurant was bustling at 830pm and another walk-in customer was willing to wait long for his takeout. Mango pudding was tasty too.
author: Kathryn H.

description:
We recently had our family Chinese New Year dinner here.  My uncle had called and made reservations for 24 people three weeks prior for 5pm on a Sunday.  But when we arrived the day of, they didn't have our reservation.   That sucked because it was a really busy Chinese New Year dinner night.  Since it was so early, they gave us the room in the back with two big tables as long as we finished by 6:30pm for the next group.  So we were in and they were rolling out the food so fast.  We went for one of the set menus so the food just kept coming and coming.  

The food was good.  Don't get me wrong about that.  It's a typical Chinese restaurant vibe.  Not the cleanest or roomiest, but it does the job.  My favorite part was the end when every single person gets there choice of dessert, not the usual everyone gets a bowl of weird bean soup or something.  I chose mango pudding.  Yum!
author: Kris L.

description:
I have to update my review again because the owners are back! Cat who's taking care of the front, takes good care of her customers. They have many good dishes including seafood and many vegetarian choices. 

My favorite are steam egg with clams, lettuce wrap and salty egg yolk pumpkin. The squabs are best in town, crispy skin with juicy meat.
author: S L.

description:
I was here for a father's day dinner with a group of 7.  We walked in without a reservation and was seated immediately.  We ordered 6 dishes, the best dish was the Peking spare ribs.  The other dishes were not bad but just on the average scale.  The most I didn't like about was the service - the waiter never came by to refill the tea and takes forever to get the check.  We actually had to fill the tea ourselves.  With this low level of service, they even had the guts to force a 15% tips on our bill.  I was really upset, but after seeing the bill only came out to be less than $60 in total, I thought the value somehow made it up for the bad service (they gave us free dessert, too).  So I gave it a two-star instead of one.  

Another thing I didn't like was the screaming little kids running in the background and the periodic earthquake sensation from the "J" Muni car.  It was not a very good dining experience.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Its been a while since I've been here. I came here ages ago when our family would come here for family dinners. Then my aunt actually moved to a place a block away on Judah but is "on the move" again. So as we helped her pack and move, we were hungry so my mom and I came here for a quick bite hoping it would be quick. Well it was quick, delicious, and affordable which should be a plus in anyones book.

We had the salted fish fried rice, and Chinese style, thai noodles. I can't really describe these typical dishes my mom loves to order. All I can say is it was nasty but its not "wow in your mouth"...its just good...how about that? Service was good and the lady was really friendly. She said I was handsome, telling my mom in Cantonese of course! The lunch also came with a soup on the house and at the end, the waitress gave us dessert too. coconut pudding or mango pudding. of course I opted. for the mango pudding which was amazeballs.

Would I come here often? Sadly no since its out of the way. but if in the area, I'd probably come back. Its tough to say tho since SF is huge and there are still so many other eats I want to explore or that I haven't tried yet. Anyhoo, if your in the Sunset I'd recommend this place to ya (Or a friend) if your in the mood for Chinese food. Four stars from me!
author: Roger C.

description:
This is probably one of the best Chinese Restaurants in the Sunset and it won't cost you an arm or a leg. For the price, the quality is very good and the portions are large, so that makes this restaurant a real bargain.  I usually get the big pea sprout leaves stir fried with garlic.  I also like beef with chinese broccoli and the chicken and corn soup.  But you probably can't go wrong with whatever you pick here.

I really like the hostess as well.  She is very friendly and funny, and she actually remembers us when we come back.  They also give a free chicken feet appetizer as well as a choice of free desserts - green bean soup, black sesame paste, mango pudding, or turtle shell jello.  I usually go for the sweet sesame paste.
author: Tyler C.

description: I had my doubts when walking inside here. Located out in the outer sunset of fog and drizzle and grey mundane buildings, this Chinese restaurant was a pleasant suprise. Definitely family style with four super large round tables and about four smaller square ones, the place was off the hook. Filled with people all eating yummy looking dishes and everyone having a good time. The place is a little rough on the edges, you are  greeted by the busboy buckets at the front door but keep moving in and get some good food. They seemed a little short staffed but even that didn't throw me off. I think the owner who was decked out in a mini skirt and some rocking jewelry and makeup was brisk but taking care of business. When she finally got to our table she apologized for all the wait and was very nice about the whole affair. Food came, won ton soup was okay, preferred a little more flavor to the broth, but everything else was delicious. Crispy chicken wings were Simply the best. Pea sprouts with garlic and szechaun eggplant was awesome. And save a little room because you get a free dessert
author: Matt A.

description: Good value, tasty, big serving, fast, friendly service, ... That's how I would sum it up.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I was sad to learn that this place changed owner last year. Who doesn't love the sweet lady owner and her great food?! I used to live a block away and came here every now and then. I didn't come back since I moved to south city two years ago. Also, I've been hearing bad experiences about this place so I didn't have a reason to come back.

Tonight the girlfriend wanted a crab dinner so I went on to yelp to find if there's any place else besides the usual PPQ or Hakka. I was like... "not sure if Yan Yan has improved". The next thing I know, thanks to Debbie K.'s post, the sweet lady is BACK!!!

Arrived at 7pm and found a space right in front of the restaurant. In case you don't know the neighborhood, finding a space in front or within the same block of where you want to go is like winning a mini lottery. We walked in and found that familiar happy face, yeah! She's indeed BACK! Long time no see and she actually recognized us.

It wasn't busy. We could seat anywhere we wanted. First thing to notice is that they have very clean stone table tops. The beautiful hand written menu on the walls are gone. I miss that. That was an art piece. Ok, on to the...

FOOD

- Chicken feet (Lo Shui): Cold complimentary app.  Really good! I kinda remembered they once served Lo Shui duck wings for comp app but my gf think not. 
- Deep fried pigeon: Very tasty with gamey flavor. Yes, pigeon should taste gamey. You know what I'm talking about if you can taste the different between a roasted duck and a roasted goose.
- Fish fillet tofu clay pot: It's ok. The sauce is flavorful without using too much starch in order to thicken it up. However, the batter is too thick on the fillet.
- Crab in Dai-Pai-Don style: Wonderful! Yes, it's greasy and super high in cholesterol. Guilty pleasure at its finest!
- Deserts: 5 offerings - Red bean sweet soup, green bean sweet soup, sesame sweet soup, turtle jelly, and last but not least mango pudding. C'mon, FIVE deserts to choose from?! This is off the hook! We've got turtle jelly and mango pudding. The turtle jelly came with a small dish of ginger syrup on the side, very thoughtful and tasted great. Well, the mango pudding... as no doubt of guess, as good as before! 

SERVICE

We need to compare apple to apple here. Granted it's a very typical hole in the wall Chinese family restaurant in the Sunset. I think the service is above average. We all know the lady owner is adorable. I still want to credit the wait staffs on doing above and beyond  what a canto family joint can offer. Dirty plates were replaced timely, tea pots were refilled, foods were placed on the table and arranged in the way that convenient to you instead of being just dropped in front of you.

CONCLUSION

Can we start a new threat on the new Yan Yan on yelp? I think it's unfair that the perilous owner had ruined its repetition. Good food, really good food, but is it the only game in town? I think PPQ and Hakka are as good around the area in terms of crab dish offerings. What stands out is the neighbor feel of it. Throughout the night we over heard that most of the customers were backed because of the owner change. Please keep on coming. Very often we drive miles to check out great restaurants. But this time I think we felt right at home.
author: Rio T.

description:
Pro: 
FREE small plate of Chicken Feet as appetizer
FREE All-you-can-eat dessert (5 choices) 
Large portions 
Decent price

Con:
Only the Lady Boss can take orders.  When it's busy, it would take some time to order your food.

Neither Pro nor Con: Dinner time usually is busy... The wait could be long if pass 6:30PM.  But, busy is good, right?  The food is fresh!
author: Q L.

description: The food here is pretty good at a reasonable price. Everything was fresh and hot and the service is attentive. I have to say the owner of this restaurant is pretty charming since she always joke with us and make us feel like we are home. Average about 120 to 200 dollars for party of 12 depends on what kind of seafood you are ordering. That's about 12 to 20 dollars per person after tax and tips which is considered fairly cheap and reasonable. I love their dessert since you get a choice of mango pudding, green bean soup, sesame paste, or turtle jelly. I think they are  nice enough to give me a second serving of the dessert if I ask for it.
author: Aylee G.

description:
I actually like eating at this Chinese restaurant compared to the others that my mom likes to take me to. The boss lady is very friendly and talkative.

I tried their Wor Wonton Soup and it was very good! I would definitely get that again because I love eating wontons. The only thing I didn't like in the soup was the pork chop--it tasted weird.

One dish I like to order to eat with rice is the chicken with snowpeas. The dish is pretty good, but I would like the dish even more if there is more snowpeas!

I like to eat their guilinggao for dessert. It's yummy.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Family and I came here last night for a random dinner night. My parents order a 3 pound  marbled rockfish and made it 2 ways. Soup and stir fry fish meat with veggie. Delics! even thought it was $18 per pound. We also had the stir fry medallion beef that had a sweet and sour sauce, Spanish with duck egg and salted duck egg, walnut prawns.  Everything was so fresh and tasty.  In the end, we had the option to choose our dessert: Red Bean Dessert, Green Bean Dessert, Seame Paste, Mango Pudding or Gulínggo.  Nice!
 The lady owner? Cat, working there was very nice and funny.  My parents enjoyed chatting with her.  She told us to come back next time and even walked us out to the door and held the door.  Very funny and easy going personality.  We might go back again.  The prices overall wasn't too bad either.
author: Selina L.

description: Great neighborhood place. The owner is super nice and the food is delicious.  We love getting the General Tsos chicken along with the Yee mein noodles.  So yummy and very reasonable too.
author: Jeff E.

description: If you are claustrophobic or mysophobic you might STILL wanna give this place a shot.  Literally a local hole in the wall dishing out some authentic Cantonese flavors, it hides itself away in a small place with dirty carpets... Ok to be fair I really don't know if they are dirty but I mean carpet n restaurants... I can only imagine that a buffet of goodies has once laid victim there.  But then again it doesn't bother me because most Chinese restaurants have carpets.  Their food is solid and they have live seafood... An absolute must.  I love their lobster e-fu noodles aka yee mein.  Had that for lunch yesterday.  Fresh live lobster stir fried with green onions n ginger over an anything but healthy fluffy soft doughy bites of yee mein.  Slap some of their tasty chili sauce on there for a light kick.  Yums!  Their braised brisket beef in a clay pot is super flavorful.  Better get off that low carb diet because you're gonna want to drench that steamy fluffy mountain of white rice with that savory sauce.  The rest of their extensive menu isn't bad... You want something you got it.  Let them know your preference n how you want it made.  Can't go wrong here.  They've been here forever so I'm sure they're doing something right.
author: Colin M.

description:
Cat is the perfect hostess and the food is a close second.

Authentic flavors, huge portions and very fair prices.

A "must" try restaurant.  

Best time to go is during day hours due to residential neighborhood.
author: Dennis Y.

description:
I'm 23 years old...and I really don't think I dress like I'm still in elementary school..

...yet, the owner here always bends down and asks me if I want Mango Pudding for dessert as if I were still a child. She does it EVERY time and it really irks me! COME ON...I'm old enough for the ADULT green/red bean desserts!

Besides that, my family likes eating dinner here. The prices are cheap and you get more than what you pay for in terms of quality AND quantity. 

I'm not a very picky eater...so this place really does it for me. 

...And I just need to mention...the Mango Pudding is actually pretty good.
author: Allan M.

description:
Go only if you know what to order. I'm hesitant to share what you should order, as there's only one thing on the menu that I absolutely love and they always seem to sell out of...but I suppose I can tell just this once.

The fire-roasted squab. I eat nothing else but the squab and rice (and maybe some veggies) when I go here. Everything else is meh. Not good, not bad. Just meh.

Oh, and be prepared for some Chinese ghetto folk (I'm Chinese myself, so I'm allowed to say that). Last time I was there with my family, two other tables (families with children, mind you!) were yelling insults at each other from across the room. Everyone else in the dining room just watched with interest and continued eating. The wait staff looked amused. I know me and my sister were, hahahaha....that was great entertainment.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
I'm so happy to found out the lady owner is back.   The food is great as usual.
This place rock
author: Eric C.

description:
Quality of Food--- 4
Ambience--- 3.5
Price--- 4
Service ---4
Average--- 3.875
author: Mary W.

description: This  is by far my favorite place for dinner with my family. The lady owner,Kat, always makes me laugh because she is hilarious, talkative, sweet, and a chill person. She has a lot of character/personality, I just love it. She also has given us free extra dessert to take home on a few occasions after we've already eaten our  desserts. I love the mango pudding here! This place is always packed when I come and doesn't have a waiting area, but that's okay since its bearable. The food comes fast and it is top notch quality and delicious! My favorite dishes are the honey walnut prawns, bbq spareribs, calamari, bbq beef with green beans, and oyster. I think this place is a tad bit more pricey than other  chinese restaurants by a few dollars for each dish, but definitely worth it for the quality and taste! My family of 5 usually eat for about $80 plus tip and we get 8 dishes and a bunch of rice. complimentary chicken feet at the beginning of the meal while you wait for your food, and complimentary dessert  at the end of the meal. I always have a good experience when I come here. Parking is a pain though.
author: Cindy L.

description: We arrived on a Saturday afternoon but they were closed. They were in the process of cleaning up after lunch and preparing for dinner. When we explained that it was our 45th wedding anniversary, the owner let us in and provided us with a wonderful meal and delightful conversation. Everything was good,:  the pot stickers, Mongolian beef, Kun Pao prawns and the mango dessert.
author: tom c.

description:
Yan Yan rocks if you are looking for good Chinese food. It's my go-to restaurant every single time if I am in the mood for Chinese food. Kat, the owner, is a riot. In a good way of course. Super cool, friendly, and entertaining a personality as it gets. Plus the service is excellent. Now onto the food. The giant clam, crab, Mongolian beef, and Yin Yang Spareribs especially rule here. You really can't go wrong with whatever entree you choose. If you are in the mood for the hk style chow mein and chow fun, they make it great here too. If you need any recommendations, just ask Kat. She always has good ideas. And this is a first for any Chinese restaurant I've ever been too. There are a handful of dessert choices for you to choose from if you eat dinner there. Normally at any particular Chinese restaurant, you'll get the standard red bean soup offered for dessert. Yan Yan however offers you that PLUS mango pudding, sweet black sesame soup, etc. You actually get choices! SCORE!

I've been here numerous of times and had good food and service every time. If you want good Chinese food, good service, and not break your piggy bank, I would highly recommend Yan Yan. Thumbs up!
author: William L.

description:
i have lived in the sunset for a long time now. this place has always been here. and you know what. they have NEVER updated or remodeled this place in the entire time. way way way overdue. but for take out this place rocks. here are the dishes that were hits - salt and pepper pork chops. crispy fried pork with a garlic and jalapeno seasoning. the best around. and the mongolian beef was very tasty. the hung tao yee wonton is the best version in the west side of SF. so much better than Kam's goopy slop. hung tao yee wonton is fried wontons in an egg drop chicken broth. hhmm hhmm good.
only bad dish was the ong choi with fermented bean cake; it did not shine. chef forgot to season the veg. maybe he figured the preserved bean cake was salty enough but it needed more garlic and then some.
still good eating after all these years.
author: Jeff W.

description: Wow!  I haven't been here for ages and I think they had new ownership sometime back as the food is just great!  This place is looks like a dirty, hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant...however, their food is really good with reasonable prices.  Must try their Dai Pai Dong Crab, beef stew w/turnip clay pot, salty egg steamed pork cake, sweet-N-Sour pork, salt-N-pepper pork, and the "Complimentary" soy sauce chicken feet!  I haven't had a dish here that didn't rock my palette so far.  Definitely my fave Chinese restaurant in the Sunset by far.  Must try~!!
author: Patrick C.

description:
I love this little pink place! My family always eats here. Yummy Chinese food!  I like how they have a variety of dessert choices instead of just the red bean dessert. 

Def a good place for some quality Chinese food!
author: A W.

description:
Comfort food that satisfies!  Kat, the gracious owner, greeted us warmly and guided us through the menu with great expertise.  We appear to be five timid 'Ladies who Lunch' with very specific tastes. Happily contented with the complimentary starter of cold chicken feet/Lo Shui; ginormous meat-stuffed potstickers; won ton seafood soup with char siu; clams in black bean sauce; salt and pepper spareribs with Peking spareribs; Garlic Pea Shoots; steamed rice and a complimentary sweet finish of Mango Puddings and a Black Sesame sweet soup, we want to be regulars here.
$41 + tax + tip = $11 per person
author: Geri S.

description:
5 solid stars to the owner, don't know her name, but we call her MAMA. 
She is definitely one of the best person in the world. Her smile made the whole meal wonderful. I didn't have much expectations upon walking in, but was impressed. I don't remember well what we had, but we ordered everything she recommended and they were all good. Spinach with three types of eggs is awesome. 

At the end of the meal, she gave us some dessert on the house, there were so many selections to choose from : mango pudding, gui ling gao, black sesame paste, and green bean` and i love them all. MAMA is the best. She walked us out and even waited us to get in the car and watched us go. Oh I miss her...~

I'm praying really hard for this place to do well :)
author: Marlis T.

description: Whenever you want Chinese food, just come here.  It's inexpensive and delicious!!  I really like the "spinich with the 1000 year old egg" Its soo good!! and the chicken wings appetizer. So delicious!
author: Emi K.

description:
ME LOVE YOU LONG TIME!

The salt and pepper squid of course! I came here for a birthday and going away party with 20+ people on a busy saturday night. For living 5 blocks away, i never thought i would step foot into this place, and thankful i did! From the outside you might be worried to try this gem, due to it being not to clean and fancy outside and being located on a empty judah street but don't let it fool you. Also mostly everyone in here or that dines here is the older chinese folks, that just shows you that you know its going to be good when you see them actually going out and paying for good food when they can make it at home.

We ordered 8-10 items for a table with 9 people and we were all full with leftovers still on the table. From crab to the shark fin soup to the honey spare ribs, everything was good and dirt cheap. Did i just say that? Yes super duper cheap! The salt and pepper squid was so good that I order togo of it now. It's full of MSG that will get you hooked like me!
author: Jacinta D.

description:
food is good. price is good. sometimes maybe a lil too greasy. but its still good (i expect that when i eat chinese)

*(i havent been since the change of ownership though)
author: Lisa N.

description:
A Chinese restaurant with sterile walls and a fish tank with hints of swamp environment. Not a shocker. As promised, I am a fair writer. Restaurants that deserve credit gets tons of blessing, and ones that are not up to par, deserve the needed spanking. My goal is to save your money/time/indisgestion from horrible restaurants.

Craving fried salt and pepper spare ribs, I wanted to eat at some value Chinese restaurant. My mom's hair cutter recommended Yan Yan on Judah St. in the Sunset district. Walking through the doorway, a seafood, no I meant a mud tank filled with seafood greeted me. Arriving at 6pm, we were the first diners. Like a ghost town, I was surprised this dilapidated restaurant had survived the times. Our waiter, a college looking young man, lacked any kind of service skills. He looked as if the owner went to the local community college, used a megaphone and yelled "anybody want to be a waiter. hurlie up!" With his over sized white shirt, he took our order. He lacked prescence and did not have any personal skills. He reminded me of a chicken who just hatched into this word. Getting a sticky feeling from the filthy floors and walls, my only hope was the food.

Food.
The salt and pepper spare ribs were under flavored. Great salt and pepper needs to be cooked the right way. Pork is flash fried in sizzling oil at high temperature. In Chinese cooking, its called "wok-air." Chilli bits are then tossed with salt and pepper mix. Dam it. Just mix it thoroughly. Our Westlake soup was simple flat in taste. The oyster based soup were showered with chives and mushroom. The beef and vegetable gave me a hint of hope. Nevertheless, the beef was though in texture. A breathe of light was the squad. Small bird fried. The result was a crispy skin with moist meat. For three, we spend $40 including tax and tip.
author: Rayfil W.

description: Set a record for the amount of time waiting to order.  30 minutes waiting in line. 30 minutes for someone to take my order.  Servers purposely ignore you.  A big problem is the boss lady is both the hostess and the person that takes your order.  Portions are big, but food is mediocre.  Definitely not worth an hour wait.  Parking in the area is also really bad.  The area is not built for restaurants.
author: R L.

description:
I went to Yan Yan site unseen tonight - solely based on Yelp reviews.

This place was so yummy!  We had the potstickers, the salt & pepper squid appetizers, then the mongolian beef (spicy), salt & pepper prawns, fried flounder, and stir-fried pea greens with garlic.  Super yummy, decent service, and the mango desert was delicious.

I will definitely go back!

Another plus - decent street parking!
author: Jennifer Z.

description: Been coming here for the past 5 years. The owner, Cat is very business savvy and has bought this restaurant back to it's better days. Better chef, extensive menu, better organization has the restaurant  busy and bustling now with satisfied customers. I've tried most standard items on the menu and have always been pleased with freshness and quality. Take out is efficient too, never having to wait very long. I can easily enjoy 3 meals out of the week here and never get tired of their food.
author: Dinah Y.

description: Yay yay for Yan Yan!  What a yummy place it was to have finally landed in a REAL Chinese joint with authentic family style prefix dinner menu!  What is also SUPER impressive is the hospitality the host/proprietor "Katz" dazzles her guests at the door, at the waiting area and throughout the restaurant seating area..She is incredible charismatic-- greets her guests with a smile and never seemed stressed by the overwhelming number of hungry hippos piling up in front of her door awaiting to be let into the feast!  Yan Yan's wait and kitchen staff deserve a standing applause as well for their unwavering labor in making their food so tasty-saliva producing and delivering them to the tables steaming fresh!  It is truly an experience to write home about.  The wait staff, unlike some notorious Chinese restaurants are actually friendly here.  They will never give you the nasty look as if you're bothering them. The food the kitchen staff cranks out at lightning speed is just unbelievable!  How they make so much yummy food in such a short amount of time is pure magic!  Pizza joints have nothing on these people!  Absolute must try items are:  General Chicken, Stir Fried Curry Crab, Shitake Mushroom on Chinese Mustard Green, Dried Fish and Chicken Fried Rice, Shrimps with glazed walnuts, Singapore Style Curry Rice Noodles and Crispy Chicken...for desert, try their Chinese sweet soups -- green or red beans or for the brave ones, the Turtle Shell Jello.  This place is a place for social dining not an ideal place for taking your date to if you want to have a dinner conversation.  Expect loud groups yacking it off while chewing their food.  It is well worth it if you have a group of friends with you!  Bon Appétit!
Good service. But....had won ton soup: No flavor. Had to pour soy sauce in to it to get some taste to the broth. Won tons were tasteless too. Won't be back.
author: Ann L.

description: I came to Yan Yan Seafood just for lunch once on a not so crowded weekday. The food that, I ordered wasnt that bad. The service at Yan Yan was okay the waiter was very helpful on what, I needed at my table. Yan Yan reminds me of Jumbo Restaurant of Noriega Street. Like on the reviews that, I was reading. I did encounter some Chinese contractors, painters, construction workers. on the day when, I went for lunch.
author: William B.

description: Food was alright, a bit too salty. Service was good. Parking at night may be difficult. Great place for dinner with family and friends.
author: Alan S.

description: This is our family favorite Chinese restaurant! Good service, great foods and yummy desserts!
author: Vincent M.

description: The freshest most delicious authentic Chinese food I've had, possibly ever. What a treat. We found this gem only recently even though it's only 2 blocks from our house. The price, quantity, and quality of the food here cannot be beat!
author: Mark S.

description:
Really wanted to give this place 4 stars, but everyone around me is going "WHHHAAAAAAAAAAAAT!!!".  So I'll avoid getting ridiculed and put 3 stars because I still have to show love to Yan Yan and their awesome, let me repeat, AWESOME salt and pepper spareribs.  Or as they say it in cantonese, JIU YEEM PAI GWUT.  My ex-roommate back in Sunset and myself, used to order one full order for each person and we could finish it.  Ignore the 2500+ calories and 3 lbs of fat that came with that dish, it is hands down my favorite salt and pepper spareribs place.  It's that perfect balance of fat, pork, spices, and a hearty serving that soothes my congested heart.

Other than that dish, I can't stand the place.  My grandparents and chinese relatives go to that place every single time we have a gathering.  Ridiculously cheap dishes, above average service, and a homely taste makes this place famous with the old chinese relatives.

JIU YEEM GWUT!!! :)
author: William C.

description:
My parents live a few blocks away, so we'll try this restaurant every once in a while.  Since then, they have changed ownership at least 4 times.  Each time the food never impressed us to make it our "regular restaurant".  Rumor had it, it again changed hands and so we're ready for another go.

The restaurant was the most packed I've seen in years.  Wow! I was a little optimistic, but then we tried the food and was sorely disappointed.  All I got to say the chef's a little trigger happy with the salt and sauces. All the dishes were drowning in them. I wanted to throw a life preserver to my poor veggies.

TIP:  This place needs some feng shui or an exorcism cuz no matter what they do or who may own it, this restaurant got bad luck...
author: Ezduzit S.

description: I grew up eating Chinese food everyday, so it's rarely my first choice of cuisine. When I do crave it, I like to come here. The lady that owns the place is like a cartoon character. She is extremely animated and friendly. My usual order consists of scallop egg white fried rice and salt & pepper tofu. She usually offers me dessert when I order to go, but noticed she doesn't do that with everyone. My family has been coming here for the last couple years and it seems to be a popular choice for many other families. They have a lot of specials on the wall, but its written in Chinese. I never learned to read Chinese, so I'm sure I'm missing out.
author: Adelina W.

description: overall great food and experience. The lady @ the front is very kind. Always come back here to dine in or to go.
author: Cell S.

description:
Having grown up in the Sunset District, I grew up eating at Yan Yan.  Don't go to this place expecting clean lines, fashionable furnishings or space between your table and the next.  Like other chinese restaurants in the Sunset, Yan Yan packs the tables in tight, the decor is an afterthought but the food is great!!

Here are some insights:

1- The steamed chicken with ginger and scallions seems to always turn out quite tender and juicy.  I don't know how they do it but I have not found another Chinese restaurant that is as consistent.

2- The seafood and tofu claypot is my new favorite dish.  Scallops, shrimp, squid, and fish are intertwined with pieces of tofu in a very tasty brownish sauce.  The flavors in this dish are unique to my tastebuds and I thoroughly enjoy adding the sauce to some steamed rice- yummmm....

3- The beef and tofu (w/out rice) is always filling and tasty.  A staple of my order each time.

4- The peking spareribs always make a mess- the sweet red sauce slathered over the deep fried pork chops are a wonderful combination.  

5- The E Fu noodles are not as good as other restaurants.

6- I hate ordering over the telephone since I don't speak Chinese.  I've found that when my mom orders over the phone, the order is always ready to go when promised.  The times when I've ordered over the phone (speaking English) my order was not ready when promised.  I'll give Yan Yan the benefit of the doubt and chalk it up to the fact that they were really busy.  However, if this keeps happening in the future I'll have decrease my rating!!  At this time, they're still worthy of 4 stars in my book.
author: Russ N.

description: Yay!  They are open again, and the original chefs and managment/owner lady are back.
author: J. L.

description: Delicious! This place never fails to satisfy. My fam comes here quite frequently since we live in the avenues. If youre a stickler on cleanliness, I  would probably rate this a 3-4 star. We ordered the westlake soup, gan pun chicken (I don't remember the English name), and beef with green onions. Yum! Oh and lady who's here all the time is super funny too!
author: Cindy S.

description: A reap off restaurant.  We have been a regularly customer of this restaurant because they have an excellent chicken wings.  However, recently we ordered 5 lbs of fried chicken wings.  When picked up the order, we could feel that it was not 5 lbs. than normally and could see the chicken wings spread out loosely on the tray.  After taken it home, we weighed again to check and found out it was only a little more than 3 lbs.  Calling back to find out why, they said that they had weighed 5 lbs. of raw chicken wings before cooking them.  It did not make any sense at all. Also they would charge tax and raised the price.   Therefore, check your order or go somewhere else.
author: Tri N.

description:
No Gway-Lo Chinese food for us here--it was pretty good.

My cousin had her going away party at Yan Yan Seafood on Friday night.  The place had a lot of empty tables so we didn't have any trouble moving from the cramped room to the main dining room.  We took up two tables...

If you ever wonder what a Cantonese family orders for a banquet-style-normal-family-get-together kind of dinner (as opposed to a 70th birthday party or a wedding banquet), this is what we had:

House Special Appetizer Platter (jelly fish, pork shank cold cuts, duck wings, and other stuff)

Fish Maw (gas bladder http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gas_bladder) Soup with Yellow Chives
Deep Fried Whole Flounder (the deep-fried bones are edible [!] and great!)
Fried Crispy Skin Chicken
Salt and Pepper Pork Chop (thin cuts)
Black Mushrooms over Mustard Greens
