Prawns with Walnuts (OK...one Gway-Lo dish.  Anything made with mayonnaise is not authentic Chinese)
Squid, Scallops, and Prawns with Vegetables (not on the menu)
Crab with Ginger and Scallions
Fried Rice with Minced Beef
Braised E-Fu Noodle with Mushrooms (Hormel Foods has a good definition for E-Fu noodles.  I don't know about their recipe though. http://www.hormel.com/kitchen/glossary.asp?id=36430)

My American-style husband still had trouble dealing with the chicken head and butt being served on the platter. But tonight was not as traumatic for him as other times--we didn't have one of the younger generation trying to pass over a plate with a fish head and asking the "grown up" table (rather loudly) if anyone wanted to suck on it before the waiter took it away.

I had an enjoyable evening with the best conversation about the Food Network in a while:

* my cousin's boyfriend thought Anthony Bourdain (http://www.anthonybourdain.com/) was an asshole and asked how Bourdain could be a good food critic when he smoked so much and drank so much alcohol--he probably couldn't taste a thing)
* my husband said Anthony Bourdain won't last 4 minutes in HIS kitchen--my God, no hat and smoking in the kitchen.
* everyone agreed that Rachael Ray (http://www.rachaelray.com/) didn't seem like she knew how to cook. Yummo your own lazy ass.
* my sister liked watching Bobby Flay (http://www.bobbyflay.com/) get his ass whipped on the cook-off show
* I told everyone I liked Rocco DiSpirito (http://www.roccodispirito.com/) and everyone wondered who the hell that was.  The ones that knew associated him with cat food (Fancy Feat Elegant Medley's)
* one cousin made a comment about two fat guys, oh whatever...
* a few cousins couldn't stand Alton Brown (http://www.altonbrown.com/)--too scientific
* I happened to love Anthony Bourdain and told them about the great blog he did on Michael Rulman's site.  He disses lots of Food Network people (http://blog.ruhlman.com/ruhlmancom/2007/02/guest_blogging_.html)

Amazing that we could have that level of conversation at a Chinese restaurant.  Usually it's so noisy we can't hear the person next to us.
author: Priscilla L.

description: This place used to be so good!  The restaurant is under new management and the service was horrible.  I ordered a beer then had to ask for it twice because they forgot.  We had to remind them to bring our order of white rice 3 times!!!  What Chinese restaurant forgets to serve the rice!  When the waiter finally noticed that the rice was missing (despite our multiple requests for them to bring it) she gasped.  I don't think we'll ever go back... so sad... This used to be our go-to restaurant for cheap Chinese food, and we loved Cat who ran the place.
author: Steffanie B.

description: Amazing!  Went with a party of 8 adults and 3 kids.  got the $110 combo that included fresh steamed swimming fish, 2 live crabs (2 ways), shrimp, clams, veggies, ribs, fried rice, and a more such that we couldn't have finished everything.  They get really busy, but that's actually a good sign these days.  Price is very reasonable considering how fresh everything was.  Oh....they also have fresh steamed cherrystone clams if you ask for them.  Excellent and my new favorite in SF--especially for the value!
author: hungry g.

description:
I LOVE this place.

The seafood and veggies are super fresh and reasonably priced.  The owner is very nice and friendly.  They give you free chicken feet before your meal and free mango pudding, sesame soup, red bean soup, and "turtle" jello after your meal.  You get to pick your choice and order as many as you want all for free.

The owner actually walks you out the door when you leave and hands you little gelatin candies.
author: Kate L.

description: We only tried the kung pao chicken, szechuan eggplant and dry fried green beans (and all to-go), but I thought the food was a solid 4 stars.  I love the eggplant.  Perfectly spicy and garlicky + generous portions to boot).  The kung pao chicken was also really good - chalked full of water chestnuts and white meat chicken. Not the gamey parts-is-parts dark meat usually served in most chinese chicken dishes.  The green beans were good.  A little soggy/greasy but great flavor.
author: Lola Z.

description: I came here with my team after a lion dance performance. It's changed ownership over the years but I can't complain if I'm not the one paying right? During lunch time, this place is always packed with Chinese contractors, painters, construction workers, you name it. I suggest coming here en masse and ordering a set dinner menu. The appetizers aren't that great but the crab dish and e-mein are pretty good. For Chinese food, this place was alright since its also close to our studio. =]
author: Jason C. J.

description:
the decor and look of this place is very typical chinese restaurant.  5 of us ordered the standard dinner for 6.  the soup was quite good, black bean sauce clams were well done, the choy was crisp and fresh, the peking spare ribs were done correctly, and the crab was excellent.

the ginger chicken and fish i thought were just average.

i dont know how this places makes money, on a thursday evening there was nobody there.  the food was good, i will be coming back.  it is in the middle of nowhere but hey, the food is good enough to bring me back.
author: Jason J.

description: I ate here with my family since it was my cousin's birthday. It was the first time eating here and we ended up ordering a LOT of stuff. I don't even know the names of the stuff we ate either. We had some mushroom chow mein, some fried fish with some type of corn, thick clear sauce, some vegetable dishes, bbq pork spare ribs, egg flower soup, fish and some other stuff I don't remember. I even tried their chicken feet (or more like TRIED to eat) but I didn't know it was cold and rubbery so I didn't end up eating it because I thought it was going to be similar to the one I tried at Dim Sum King which wasn't bad at all. The owner was a very nice lady and funny too. We then had our choices for dessert of either sesame paste, red bean paste or mango pudding. I got mango pudding which was good. Overall, all the dishes I tried were okay. Nothing really gave me a wow in my mouth to really like it. Very fast and good service though.
author: Sean E.

description: Having read about this gem in a small unassuming area of the sunset, Judah for that matter, I finally stopped in for some take out last night.  I love the dragon like design of the ceiling tiles and white walls with pink table cloths, traditional and simple.  The service is very friendly and prices reasonable.  The pot stickers are wonderful; crispy golden yet not doughy with a wonderful ground pork, ginger, and cabbage filling.  The egg rolls, though a little greasy, are good with a crispy badder for the most part and a wonderful ground pork and vegetable filling.  The chicken crispy mein is wonderful with tender chicken and fresh vegetables over crispy noodles that are not soggy from the gravy.  The Hong Kong spareribs are crispy and tender with just the perfect amount of sweet and sour sauce which is pretty much glazed on with sweet pineapple.  AS a Caucasian, I love speaking the limited amount of Cantonese I know; so when said thank and bye bye, I the two waitresses and waiter were all marbled.  I will definitely return.  Oh, my mother went next door to Lets Cupcake (see my review) while we waited and the waitress here at Yan Yan gave us a bag for the box of sweet delights which was another personal touch.  So, for excellent Cantonese cuisine at reasonable prices with friendly service in a casual clean atmosphere, Yan Yan cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: We have been back to Yan Yan a few more times since my last post. The foods remain excellent, but the service is not quite the same. The nice waiter who came to change our plates were not there any more, and we had to request for clean plates. Although the woman owner is friendly,  she does not always come around to see if all was going well -- we had to ask for more paper napkins, and tea. Having said that, we would still go back for the delicious food and give it a 4 star. As for the service, it deserves a 3.
author: Lisa C.
